The trochlea-capitellar axis is 6 degrees off a line perpendicular to the humerus, resulting in a valgus carrying angle of the forearm (mean 7 degrees in men, 13 degrees in women, disappearing with flexion). The radiohumeral joint is poorly congruent, while the ulnohumeral joint is highly congruent. The capitellum's smaller radius than the radial head allows rotation in any flexion position, stabilized by the annular ligament.

The humerus has a neck-shaft angle of 130 degrees and 30 degrees retroversion. The humeral head is eccentric, positioned 9mm posterior to the shaft's central axis. The glenoid is tilted 5 degrees superiorly and retroverted 7 degrees from the scapula's plane, resulting in an overall glenoid anteversion of 25-35 degrees. The clavicle is fixed to the scapula by coracoclavicular ligaments, and ACJ/CC ligament disruption can lead to scapulothoracic instability.

Elbows have short lever arms for forces, making them inefficient and predisposed to arthritis due to high ulnohumeral joint reaction forces. In a free body diagram, extension moment equals flexion moment, and JRF can be calculated. Forces in extension include hand load, forearm weight, and JRF. Flexion involves the pull of elbow flexors.

IP joints are single-axis hinge joints, with static stability provided by bony architecture, collateral ligaments, and the volar plate. MP joints allow 2 axes of movement (flexion/extension and abduction/adduction), with the latter occurring only if the proximal phalanx (P1) is flexed 30 degrees. CMC joints of the fingers become progressively more restricted in movement towards the ulna, with the 4th and 5th CMCJs being rigid and transmitting forces to the wrist.

The scaphoid spans both carpal rows, creating a distal flexion and proximal extension moment with the radioscaphocapitate ligament as the fulcrum. A scaphoid waist fracture leads to a humpback deformity. SLAC wrist involves disruption of the SL ligament, causing scaphoid flexion and impingement on the radius, leading to arthrosis. SNAC wrist typically results from a fracture, causing a humpback deformity and impingement.

IP joints are hinge joints, while MP and CMC joints allow for more complex movements. The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint enabling circumduction. The extensor mechanism includes long extensors, intrinsics, and sagittal bands. The flexor mechanism involves FDP and FDS tendons, with the "Quadrigia effect" occurring when one FDP tendon is tethered. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to finger adduction and abduction.

In a normal knee, the medial femoral condyle (MFC) is larger and more distal, while the medial tibial plateau is lower and more concave. The lateral tibial plateau is higher and convex. The lower limb mechanical axis passes just medial to the lateral tibial spine, with the normal tibial plateau having a 3-degree varus to the mechanical axis. TKR cuts are perpendicular to prevent uneven loading.

In a single leg stance, the ground reaction force (GRF) is influenced by the abductor force and body weight. The abductor force counteracts body weight to maintain pelvic elevation and normal gait. In osteoarthritis, the loss of frictionless cartilage increases the abductor force and joint reaction force (JRF), leading to pain.

The knee joint is complex, with articular congruity varying between the medial and lateral tibial plateaus. The menisci play a crucial role in load transmission and rotation. Ligaments, including the ACL, PCL, MCL, and LCL, provide stability. The ACL has anteromedial and posterolateral bundles, while the PCL has anterolateral and posteromedial bundles.

The Achilles tendon transfers approximately 10 times body weight during terminal stance and pre-swing. Clinical features of tendinopathy include activity-related pain and swelling. Examination involves assessing swelling location and using tests like Symmonds test for tendon continuity. Imaging may show Haglund's deformity or calcaneal cystic changes.

The medial longitudinal arch provides shock absorption and propulsion. It is not rigid but varies its function during gait. Stabilizers include the plantar fascia, spring ligament, and other ligaments. During gait, tibial rotation and subtalar joint motion allow for arch adaptation.

topics.topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
topics.text: Functional goals for the foot and ankle include flexibility and rigidity depending on gait phase. The joints transmit significant body weight, acting as a rigid lever arm during push-off and being supple during stance. Movements include dorsiflexion/plantarflexion (sagittal plane), varus/valgus (coronal plane, hindfoot), abduction/adduction (transverse plane, midfoot), and pronation/supination (combined movements at multiple joints).

The plantar fascia originates at the calcaneus and inserts into all tarsal joints and the proximal phalanges. It acts as a truss, supporting the arches and operating via the windlass mechanism. When the MTPJs are extended, the plantar fascia tightens, locking the tarsal joints and increasing longitudinal arch height, making the foot a rigid lever for push-off.

The talus has no muscle attachments and is cradled by tendons and ligaments. The subtalar joint acts as a torque converter, translating tibial rotation into foot supination/pronation. The subtalar joint has 20 degrees of inversion and 5 degrees of eversion, with a normal axis of about 45 degrees. Flat feet have a more horizontal subtalar axis, while cavus feet have a more vertical axis.

Tarsometatarsal joint motion is restricted to less than 5 degrees of dorsiflexion and 15 degrees of plantarflexion, due to bony architecture and strong ligaments. These joints form the transverse arch of the midfoot, with the 2nd tarsometatarsal joint (Lisfranc's joint) at its center. The dorsal aspect is under compression, and the plantar aspect is under tension.

Spinal stability, as defined by White and Panjabi, is the ability to resist displacement under physiologic loading to protect neural structures and prevent deformity and pain. A motion segment consists of two vertebrae and intervening soft tissues, with stability conferred by passive (musculoskeletal), active (musculoskeletal), and neural subsystems.

Clinical gait analysis involves inspecting for wasting, scars, asymmetry, malalignment, and prosthetics, and observing normal movements of the pelvis, hips, knees, ankles, and feet during the gait cycle. Pelvic rotation occurs at heel strike and toe-off, with tilting during swing for clearance. Hip flexion aids clearance, and extension prevents collapse.

Gait can be assessed clinically or with a gait analysis lab. Prerequisites for normal walking include stable stance phase, adequate step distance, foot clearance during swing, energy conservation, and pre-positioning of the foot in swing. Gait smoothness is achieved by pelvic tilt, lateral displacement, and rotation, along with knee flexion and ankle/foot motion.

The gait cycle begins with foot strike and ends with the same foot striking again, comprising stance (60%) and swing (40%) phases. It is divided into eight sub-phases from heel strike to heel strike. Key definitions include step length, stride length, cadence, and double support phase.

During gait, dorsiflexors are concentric throughout swing, while plantarflexors are inactive. Dorsiflexors are eccentric at initial contact (1st rocker), plantarflexors are eccentric at midstance (2nd rocker), and plantarflexors are concentric at pre-swing (toe-off, 3rd rocker). Glutei are inactive in swing and active throughout stance, while quads and hamstrings show eccentric activity at various phases.

Cerclage wire's tensile strength is proportional to its diameter, and it is notch sensitive. Cables have higher fatigue resistance. Screws convert rotatory load to linear motion, producing compression. Pullout force increases with screw diameter, embedded length, bone quality, surface area, cortical purchase, and pitch. Cannulated screws have lower pullout strength due to reduced core diameter.

Biomechanics involves the study of forces acting on the body. Newton's three laws of motion are fundamental: Inertia (a body remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a force), Acceleration (force equals mass times acceleration), and Reaction (every action has an equal and opposite reaction).

Force is a mechanical load with direction, which can be plotted on x, y, and z-axes. The Pythagorean theorem helps calculate an unknown force if two other forces are known. A vector introduces the concept of direction, and a force vector represents the direction of a force.

Newton's laws are fundamental to biomechanics. The first law (inertia) explains static analysis, the second law (F=ma) relates force, mass, and acceleration in dynamic analysis, and the third law (actions and reactions) describes the interaction between bodies.

Scalar quantities have magnitude but no direction (e.g., mass, speed), while vector quantities have both magnitude and direction (e.g., force, velocity). Vector quantities can be resolved into components for analysis.

Stress is the internal force per unit area within a material, while strain is the relative measure of deformation. Hooke's law states that stress is proportional to strain within the elastic limit, and Young's modulus (E) measures a material's stiffness.

Free body diagrams are used to analyze static forces and moments acting on a joint. In static analysis, all variables must be zero. Six variables are present: force in x, y, and z axes, and the moments created in these axes. Seven assumptions are made for free body analysis: frictionless joints, only compressive forces, equal internal forces, no antagonistic muscle action, rigid bones, muscle force in the direction of the belly, and concentrated body weight.

Joint lubrication prevents wear. Boundary lubrication involves surfaces separated by a molecularly thin lubricant, predominant in prosthetic joints. Fluid film lubrication occurs when a thicker fluid film separates surfaces, dominating in native joints and MoM articulations. Hydrodynamic lubrication relies on the generation of a fluid wedge. Elastohydrodynamic lubrication involves articular cartilage deformation.

Kinematics is the study of motion (acceleration, velocity, displacement) without considering the forces causing it. Work is defined as force multiplied by the degree of displacement. Energy is a measure of work, is never created or destroyed, and is transferred between types and bodies, with the sum total always remaining constant.

The body functions as a system of levers with three classes, determined by the position of the force, fulcrum, and load. First-class levers have the fulcrum in the middle (e.g., atlanto-axial joint, scissors). Second-class levers have the load in the middle (e.g., nutcracker), requiring less force to overcome the load. Third-class levers, the most common in the body, have the force in the middle and require more force to overcome the load (e.g., shovel, forearm).

topics.topic: Newton's Law of Viscosity and Synovial Fluid
topics.text: Newton's law of viscosity describes the relationship between shear stress and shear rate. Synovial fluid, however, is a non-Newtonian fluid that exhibits pseudoplasticity and thixotropy, meaning its viscosity changes with shear rate and time under load. This property is crucial for joint lubrication during movement.

Perren's Strain Theory states that fracture healing tissue type is dictated by interfragmentary strain. Optimal strain for primary bone healing is <2%, for hard callus 5%, and for soft callus 10%. Too little strain leads to non-union, while too much strain impairs hard callus formation and can cause hypertrophic non-union.

Stress is force applied per unit area, measured in Pascals. Strain is the change in length relative to original length, a unitless measure. Material properties are subject to applied forces; isotropic materials have properties independent of force direction, while anisotropic materials vary. The stress-strain curve illustrates these relationships.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
topics.text: Joint lubrication mechanisms include Boundary lubrication (single molecular layer, predominant in prostheses), Squeeze Film lubrication (fluid pressure resisting load, predominant in native joints), Elastohydrodynamic lubrication (fluid deformation), Hydrodynamic lubrication (fluid film lifting surfaces), Weeping lubrication (compression elutes fluid), and Boosted lubrication (pressurized fluid leaves viscous residue). These work in concert during the gait cycle.

Moment is the effect of a force at a distance, causing rotation or angular movement. Torque is the magnitude of a moment. Couples are pairs of forces creating the same moment, such as opening a bottle cap with two fingers.

Potential energy is stored energy, while kinetic energy is the energy required to stop a moving body (E=1/2MV). Power is work done per unit time, and momentum is a body's mass multiplied by its velocity. Speed is the measure of distance traveled over time without direction.

The mechanical axis of the knee is slightly anterior to the midpoint of the plateau, balanced by the posterior capsule and ligaments. The tibial slope is normally 7 degrees posterior, with the lateral plateau having a slightly greater slope. The flexion-extension axis corresponds to the transepicondylar line. Femoral rollback occurs during flexion, increasing the lever arm for the quadriceps.

Differential femoral rollback results in a polycentric instant center of rotation. The lateral femoral condyle (LFC) externally rotates during flexion (relative tibial internal rotation) and internally rotates during extension (relative tibial external rotation). The knee screws home and locks in full extension, a stable position where the cruciates are also taught.

The popliteus muscle arises from the posteromedial tibia and acts to unlock the knee from extension by causing femoral external rotation and tibial internal rotation. The patella functions as a pulley to increase the quadriceps lever arm; patellectomy reduces quadriceps power by 20%.

The Q angle, formed by the quadriceps and patellar tendon lines, is normally 5-20 degrees and tends to be higher in women. Increased Q angle can result from conditions like genu varum, genu valgum, or lateralization of the tibial tuberosity, leading to lateral patellar pull and potential instability. Patellofemoral arthrosis can be caused by increased Q angle, shallow trochlea, or deficient medial patella facet.

Normal patellofemoral motion involves the patella engaging the trochlea at 20 degrees flexion and conforming to the groove in deep flexion. The patella is most prone to instability in extension. Contact pressures are highest on the patella, with the thickest cartilage (1 cm) at the patellofemoral joint.

Restraints to abnormal knee motion include static restraints like the ACL (anteromedial bundle tight in flexion, posterolateral in extension) and PCL (anterolateral tight in flexion, posteromedial in extension), as well as collaterals and the ITB. Dynamic restraints include the quadriceps. Varus is primarily resisted by the LCL and posterolateral corner, while valgus is resisted by the MCL and posteromedial corner.

Knee arthroplasty aims for conformational matching between the femur and tibia to minimize wear and ensure stability. Fully constrained knees move in one plane, reducing wear but increasing stress at the implant-bone interface. Fully unconstrained designs allow greater motion but can lead to edge loading and wear. Failure modes include loosening, instability, maltracking, overstuffing, poor fixation, and infection.

Goals of Total Knee Replacement (TKR) include reducing pain, improving function, maintaining ROM, and avoiding complications through biomechanical principles like restoring the mechanical axis, preserving joint line, creating equal flexion/extension gaps, balancing ligaments, and ensuring durable component fixation.

Design variables in TKR include component conformity (trade-off between wear, ROM, and loosening), fixation method (cemented or uncemented), femoral radius of curvature, polyethylene properties (type, thickness), and level of constraint (PCL retaining vs. sacrificing). Polyethylene thickness is crucial, with an 8mm minimum and 10mm preferred to avoid increased wear.

Increasing the abductor force or moment arm (e.g., carrying a suitcase, lateralizing the greater trochanter, using a high offset stem) increases JRF and pain. Reducing body weight (losing weight, Trendelenberg gait, using a stick) or medializing the cup (small head size, thin polyethylene) can reduce JRF.

Glenohumeral motion is primarily responsible for the initial 30 degrees of abduction and 60 degrees of flexion/extension. The rotator cuff stabilizes the humeral head and acts as a fulcrum for the deltoid. Scapulothoracic motion involves inferior translation of the humeral head with shoulder movement, requiring scapular movement for glenoid articulation. Loss of this motion can lead to instability.

The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint with 2 axes of movement, similar to finger MCPJs. Circumduction occurs due to these two axes. The trapezium and metacarpal base have differing radii of curvature, allowing thumb pronation and increased ROM but reduced stability. The volar oblique ligament is crucial for thumb CMCJ stability but is prone to attenuation/rupture.

The passive system includes vertebrae, discs, facet joints, ligaments, and joint capsules. Vertebrae increase in width and depth caudally, with internal structure featuring vertical and horizontal trabeculae. Loss of trabeculae due to osteoporosis predisposes to compression fractures. The saggital shape of the spine allows body weight to be away from the central axis of rotation, aiding balance and gait.

Facet joints determine the type of movement between vertebrae and become more vertical caudally. The cervical spine is susceptible to flexion/extension due to facet obliquity, while the lumbar spine is more resistant. The thoracic spine has added stability from the rib cage. Spinal ligaments, such as the ligamentum flavum, PLL, and ALL, provide resistance to motion and can contribute to stenosis when degenerated.

The active system comprises the spinal musculature, including extensors, abdominal muscles, intercostals, and lower trunk muscles. The neural subsystem refers to proprioception, crucial for maintaining spinal stability during movement. Spinal range of motion includes a neutral zone (high flexibility) and an elastic zone (passive system predominates).

In spinal disease or injury, the neutral zone increases, leading to a wider range of motion and potential for neurologic injury. Muscle strengthening can help minimize this increase in the neutral zone.

topics.topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
topics.text: The ankle provides 20 degrees of dorsiflexion (DF) and 30 degrees of plantarflexion (PF), with the foot contributing to the remaining motion. Tibial rotation during gait is approximately 11 degrees. At heel strike, the ankle is in neutral or slight PF, progressing to further PF in early stance and DF during mid-stance.

topics.topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
topics.text: Kinetics of the ankle show a large contact area, resulting in less arthritis compared to the hip or knee. However, the ankle is sensitive to disruption. A 1mm taller shift increases contact pressure significantly, potentially leading to early arthritis. Plantarflexors are active during stance to maintain an upright posture.

Age-related changes to gait include a broad-based stiff knee gait at 18 months, adult gait by 7 years, with minimal changes until 70 years. After 70, velocity and step length decrease, and the double support phase increases. Females tend to have a faster cadence due to shorter stature but similar velocity.

Abnormalities of gait include Trendelenberg gait (due to abductor weakness or short lever arm), anterior trunk bending (often from knee extension failure or weak hip extensors), posterior trunk bending (to overcome hip extension inability), and increased lumbar lordosis (compensating for hip flexion deformity).

Abnormal hip rotation can result from femoral version or muscle imbalance, leading to altered foot progression angles. Excessive knee extension is often seen in quad weakness, causing anterior bending to compensate. Excessive knee flexion can be due to fixed flexion or spastic hamstrings.

Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion causes foot slap and toe drag. Insufficient push-off occurs with gastrocnemius weakness or Achilles rupture. Wide-based gait is adopted for stability in conditions like ataxia or obesity. Pathologic gaits include steppage gait (equinus deformity), hip scissoring gait (spastic adductors), and antalgic gait (limping to reduce pain).

Squeeze film lubrication occurs during non-sliding contact, building pressure to maintain a gap. Boosted lubrication involves pressurizing synovial fluid into the cartilage, creating a more viscous fluid. Weeping lubrication involves compression eluting lubricant fluid. The predominant lubrication type varies with gait cycle phase.

In prosthetic joints, boundary and some fluid film lubrication may occur. Wettability describes a material's affinity for lubricant, with ceramics being highly wettable. Large diameter articulations benefit from true fluid film lubrication if the effective radius is large and surface roughness is low.

The stress-strain curve shows the toe region (uncoiling of fibers), elastic region (linear, Hooke's Law applies), proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, strain hardening, ultimate tensile strength, and fracture. Strain energy is the area under the elastic portion of the curve.

Brittle materials have little plastic behavior, with yield and fracture points close together (e.g., ceramic). Ductile materials have a large plastic region (e.g., metals). Hardness is a surface property. Fatigue failure occurs due to repetitive stress below ultimate tensile strength, represented by the S-N curve. Stiffness refers to resisting deformation, while rigidity is structural ability to resist deformation.

Nails are advantageous as they reside within the bone's axis and act as load-sharing devices. Metaphyseal fractures are problematic due to bending moments and lack of cortical contact around the nail. Plates are more susceptible to failure than nails due to lower bending rigidity and reliance on fracture reduction.

Locking plates form fixed-angle constructs, eliminating the weak screw-plate interface and screw pullout. Their stiffness depends on screw thickness and material. They preserve periosteal blood supply and can be inserted minimally invasively. Proper articular reduction and fixation are crucial before applying locking screws.

Bone is subjected to combined forces: shear, bending, torsion, compression, and tension. Strength is the ability to resist deformation, dependent on material properties and shape. Rectangular structures resist bending, while tubular structures are more vulnerable to torsion. Stiffness is a material property related to stress/strain, while rigidity is a structural property.

Cerclage wire's tensile strength is proportional to diameter and it is notch sensitive. Cables have higher fatigue resistance. Screws convert rotatory load to linear motion, producing compression. Pullout force increases with screw diameter, embedded length, bone quality, and surface area. Locking plates offer fixed-angle constructs, eliminating screw pullout and improving stiffness.

Nails reside within the bone's axis and act as load-sharing devices. Metaphyseal fractures are prone to failure due to bending moments and lack of cortical contact. Plates have lower bending rigidity than nails and are more susceptible to failure. External fixation provides adaptable fixation, with stiffness influenced by pin size, working length, and number/placement of pins.

Perren's Strain Theory states that fracture healing tissue type depends on interfragmentary strain. Optimal strain for primary bone healing is <2%, hard callus is 5%, and soft callus is 10%. Too little strain leads to non-union, while excessive strain impairs callus formation and can cause non-union or pseudoarthrosis. Adverse effects on healing include poor blood supply, smoking, NSAIDs, and head injury.

Pullout force increases with screw diameter, embedded length, bone quality, surface area, and pitch. Locking plates provide fixed-angle constructs, eliminating screw pullout and improving stiffness.

Nails reside within the bone's axis and act as load-sharing devices, though metaphyseal fractures can be problematic. Plates have lower bending rigidity than nails and are more susceptible to failure. External fixation provides adaptable fixation, with stiffness influenced by pin size, working length, and number/placement of pins.

Knee arthroplasty design principles focus on restoring mechanical alignment, joint line, and ligament balance. Modern TKRs aim for normal femoral rollback. PCL retaining designs offer advantages but are technically demanding, while PCL substituting designs offer more conformity but may increase stress transfer to bone. Mobile bearing knees allow greater conformity and minimize wear but have unique problems like poly spin out.

Patellofemoral issues like maltracking and patella baja can lead to TKR failure. Management of bone loss in TKR involves classification systems (Paprosky) and various reconstructive options like impaction grafting, augments, and cages. Femoral and acetabular component selection considers patient anatomy and desired outcomes.

Shoulder anatomy includes the humerus, glenoid, and clavicle, with glenohumeral motion driven by the rotator cuff and deltoid. Scapulothoracic motion is essential for glenoid articulation. Glenohumeral stability is maintained by static stabilizers (labrum, geometry, ligaments) and dynamic stabilizers (muscles, proprioception).

The scaphoid spans both carpal rows, creating flexion and extension moments. Wrist stability involves intrinsic and extrinsic carpal ligaments. SLAC and SNAC wrists result from ligament or scaphoid instability, leading to arthrosis. The DRUJ is a modified hinge joint stabilized by the TFCC.

Spinal stability is maintained by passive (vertebrae, discs, ligaments), active (musculature), and neural subsystems. The spine's saggital shape and facet joint orientation influence movement and stability. Age-related changes lead to disc dehydration, reduced mobility, and increased risk of spinal canal stenosis.

Intervertebral discs, composed of annulus fibrosus and nucleus pulposus, provide shock absorption and mobility. Disc degeneration involves dehydration and changes in collagen and proteoglycan content. Herniation occurs when the annulus tears, potentially causing nerve impingement. Spinal ligaments (ALL, PLL, ligamentum flavum) are crucial for stability.

The hand has complex biomechanics involving IP, MP, and CMC joints, each with specific axes of movement and stability. The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint enabling crucial functions like opposition. Tendons are organized into zones based on their location and the pulley system that prevents bowstringing.

Flexor tendons are extrinsic and intrinsic, with FDP being a mass action muscle. The "Quadrigia effect" occurs when one FDP tendon is tethered, causing slight flexion in other digits. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension. Intrinsic paralysis leads to a "intrinsic minus" hand with MCPJ hyperextension.

The carpus comprises two rows of bones, with the proximal row being an intercalated segment stabilized by bony geometry and extrinsic ligaments. Carpal kinematics involve flexion/extension at the radiocarpal joint and radial/ulna deviation at the midcarpal joint. Carpal instability is classified as dissociative (within rows) or non-dissociative (between rows), with CID and CIC representing complex patterns.

Glenohumeral stability relies on static stabilizers (labrum, geometry, ligaments) and dynamic stabilizers (muscles, proprioception).

The carpus has two rows of bones, with the proximal row being an intercalated segment stabilized by bony geometry and ligaments. Carpal kinematics involve flexion/extension at the radiocarpal joint and radial/ulna deviation at the midcarpal joint. Carpal instability is classified as dissociative or non-dissociative, with complex patterns involving both.

The hand's biomechanics involve IP, MP, and CMC joints with specific movements and stability. The thumb CMCJ's saddle joint allows crucial functions like opposition. Tendons are organized into zones, with the pulley system preventing bowstringing. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension.

Spinal stability is maintained by passive (vertebrae, discs, ligaments), active (musculature), and neural subsystems. The spine's saggital shape and facet joint orientation influence movement and stability. Age-related changes lead to disc degeneration, reduced mobility, and increased risk of spinal canal stenosis.

The carpus has two rows of bones, with the distal row rigidly fixed and the proximal row acting as an intercalated segment. Carpal stability relies on intrinsic and extrinsic ligaments. Kinematics involve flexion/extension at the radiocarpal joint and radial/ulna deviation at the midcarpal joint. Carpal instability is classified as dissociative, non-dissociative, or complex, with DISI and VISI patterns representing specific postures.

Implants are subject to various forces like shear, bending, torsion, compression, and tension. Strength and stiffness are material properties influenced by composition, shape, and manufacturing. Locking plates offer fixed-angle constructs, eliminating screw pullout and improving stiffness. External fixation provides adaptable fixation, with stiffness dependent on pin size and working length.

The shoulder's stability relies on glenohumeral and scapulothoracic motion. Static stabilizers include the labrum, articular geometry, GH ligaments, and capsule. Dynamic stabilizers are the rotator cuff, biceps tendon, and scapular rotators. Reverse shoulder arthroplasty is indicated for pseudoparalysis or cuff deficiency, altering the center of rotation to utilize the deltoid.

Elbows have short lever arms, making them inefficient and prone to arthritis due to high ulnohumeral joint reaction forces. Free body diagrams analyze extension and flexion moments, with JRF calculated based on forces acting on the joint. Levers are measured in meters.

In single leg stance, the ground reaction force (GRF) is influenced by abductor force and body weight. Abductor force counteracts body weight to maintain pelvic stability. Osteoarthritis can increase abductor force and joint reaction force (JRF), leading to pain. Reducing body weight or medializing the cup can decrease JRF.

The hand's biomechanics involve IP, MP, and CMC joints. IP joints are hinge joints. MP joints allow flexion/extension and abduction/adduction. CMC joints restrict movement towards the ulna, with the 3rd MC acting as a cantilever. The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint enabling opposition. Tendons are organized into zones, with the pulley system preventing bowstringing.

The medial longitudinal arch provides shock absorption and propulsion. It is not rigid but varies its function during gait. Stabilizers include the plantar fascia, spring ligament, and other ligaments. Tibial rotation and subtalar joint motion contribute to arch mechanics.

Tendons are organized into zones, with the pulley system preventing tendon bowstringing. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
topics.text: Joint lubrication involves several mechanisms: Squeeze Film lubrication (fluid pressure), Elastohydrodynamic lubrication (fluid deformation), Hydrodynamic lubrication (fluid film), Weeping lubrication (fluid elution from cartilage), Boosted lubrication (pressurized fluid residue), and Boundary lubrication (molecular layer). These work dynamically during gait.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
topics.text: Joint lubrication mechanisms include Boundary, Squeeze Film, Elastohydrodynamic, Hydrodynamic, Weeping, and Boosted lubrication. These work together during the gait cycle to reduce friction and wear between articular surfaces. Boundary lubrication is crucial for prosthetic joints.

topics.topic: Newton's Law of Viscosity and Synovial Fluid
topics.text: Synovial fluid is a non-Newtonian fluid, exhibiting pseudoplasticity and thixotropy, meaning its viscosity changes with shear rate and time under load. This property is essential for joint lubrication, allowing fluid to resist load during gait and providing a low-friction interface.

Potential energy is stored energy, while kinetic energy is the energy required to stop a moving body (E=1/2MVÂ2). Power is work done per unit time, and momentum is a body's mass multiplied by its velocity. Speed is the measure of distance traveled over time without direction.

Adamantinoma is a rare, low-grade malignant tumor, typically found in young adults with a predilection for the tibia (90% diaphyseal). It may arise from cortical fibrous dysplasia and causes long-standing pain and swelling, with occasional soft tissue masses. Radiographically, it presents as multiple diaphyseal lytic areas with sclerosis, often with a "soap bubble" appearance. Management involves wide local excision and reconstruction, as chemotherapy and radiotherapy are not effective.

Chondrosarcomas are malignant tumors of cartilage, with subtypes including classic intramedullary, de-differentiated, clear cell, and mesenchymal chondrosarcoma. Intramedullary chondrosarcomas are more common in older patients (>45 years) and have a better prognosis if low grade. De-differentiated chondrosarcomas are aggressive and require wide resection combined with chemotherapy.

Chordomas are malignant tumors arising from notochordal remnants, typically affecting individuals over 40. They occur in the midline spine, primarily in the sacrum and cranio-occipital region, and can metastasize late to the lungs. Imaging shows a sacral mass with calcification and bony destruction. Management is wide excision, with radiotherapy for inadequate margins.

Ewing's Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor primarily affecting males under 20 years old. It is of unknown etiology but involves a translocation of the t(11;22) chromosome. Clinically, it presents with pain and fever, mimicking infection, and often forms a large soft tissue mass that metastasizes to the lungs and other bones. Radiographically, it shows purely lytic lesions with a "moth-eaten" appearance and concentric periosteal reaction (onion skin).

Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor similar in features to osteosarcoma but without osteoid production. It typically affects individuals over 40 and presents with pain and swelling. Management involves chemotherapy-sensitive treatment, with outcome generally worse than osteosarcoma. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) is also similar but lacks spindle cells and osteoid production.

Primary lymphoma of bone can occur at any age but is more common in middle-aged adults and males. It presents as a large, warm, soft tissue mass with swollen, painful lymph nodes, weight loss, fever, and night pain. Imaging shows permeative lytic lesions with mottled appearance and high uptake on bone scan. Management includes multiagent chemotherapy and radiotherapy for chronic control.

Malignant bone tumors are classified by histological cell of origin: osteogenic (Osteosarcoma), chondrogenic (Chondrosarcoma), fibrogenic (Fibrosarcoma, MFH), notochordal (Chordoma), vascular (Haemangioendothelioma), hemopoietic (Lymphoma, Myeloma), miscellaneous (Ewing's Sarcoma, Adamantinoma), and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma is the most common malignant bone tumor, typically affecting young adults and children, with intramedullary osteosarcoma being the most frequent subtype.

Multiple myeloma is the most common malignant bone tumor, typically affecting individuals over 50, more commonly men and those of black ethnicity. It arises from plasma cells and produces abnormal proteins, inhibiting osteoblasts and stimulating osteoclasts. Clinical features include bone pain, pathologic fractures (especially spine), renal failure, and hypercalcemia. Imaging shows punched-out lytic lesions, and bone scans are negative due to osteoblast inactivation.

Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, de-differentiated, clear cell, mesenchymal), post-radiotherapy, and Paget's disease-associated. Prognosis correlates with grade; de-differentiated chondrosarcoma has the worst prognosis. Histologic features like 'soap bubble appearance' or 'chicken wire calcification' aid in diagnosis.

Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic), post-radiotherapy, and Paget's disease-associated osteosarcomas. Intramedullary is most common, often around the knee, while parosteal is low-grade and on the bone surface. Prognosis correlates with grade, subtype, and presence of metastases.

Classic intramedullary osteosarcoma has an unknown etiology but is associated with retinoblastoma gene and p53 translocation. It typically arises at the meta-diaphyseal junction, most commonly around the knee. Presentation includes short-history pain, a mass, and sometimes pathologic fracture. Imaging shows simultaneous bone formation and lysis, with Codman's triangle and sunray spicules. Management involves neo-adjuvant chemotherapy followed by wide or radical surgical resection.

Poor prognostic indicators for osteosarcoma include high LDH and alkaline phosphatase levels, absence of anti-shock protein 90, pelvic location, pathologic fracture at presentation, poor tumor necrosis after chemotherapy, vascular invasion, recurrence, and metastases.

Clear Cell Sarcoma is a rare soft tissue sarcoma affecting young adults (20-40 years), predominantly females. It involves translocation of chromosomes 12 and 22 and is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot, often associated with tendon sheaths. It produces melanin, mimicking malignant melanoma of soft parts. Management is typically wide excision and radiotherapy.

Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma, affecting older adults and typically arising in deep tissues. It can be low, intermediate, or high grade, with myxoid liposarcoma being the most common. Pathology shows signet cells. Management depends on grade, with low-grade tumors treated by marginal excision and high-grade tumors by wide excision with adjuvant therapy.

MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults (>55 years), presenting as a slow-growing, painless mass that may cause systemic symptoms. It is characterized by haphazard, pleomorphic histiocytic cells and a storiform appearance. Management is chemo-sensitive, similar to osteosarcoma.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are called sarcomas and are classified by tissue of origin (e.g., liposarcoma, fibrosarcoma). They are more common in older patients, males, and have a centripetal growth pattern. Worrying clinical features include rapid growth, pain, large size (>5cm), and neurovascular symptoms. MRI is often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management typically involves wide excision and adjuvant therapy (except for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma).

Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, often associated with the NF2 gene. They present as slow-growing, painless masses that may cause neurological symptoms. Imaging shows low T1 and high T2 signal. Management is typically wide excision with radiotherapy, with better survival for solitary lesions than those associated with NF1.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood, presenting as a fast-growing, painless mass. It is chemotherapy-sensitive and radiotherapy is used for incomplete margins. Outcomes are better in children than adults. Leiomyosarcoma is a smooth muscle tumor similar to rhabdomyosarcoma and often involves blood vessels.

Synovial sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in young adults (14-40 years), associated with SYT gene abnormality and t(X;18) translocation. It presents as a highly malignant, high-grade lesion, most commonly in the foot, and affects para-articular regions. Imaging shows low T1 and high T2 signal with calcifications. Management considers chemotherapy as an adjunct to surgery.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically into osteogenic (Osteoid Osteoma, Osteoblastoma), chondrogenic (Chondroma, Enchondroma, Chondroblastoma), fibrogenic (Non-ossifying Fibroma, Desmoplastic Fibroma, Chondromyxoid Fibroma), cystic (Unicameral Bone Cyst, Aneurysmal Bone Cyst), and of unknown origin (GCT, Langerhans cell histiocytosis). The Enneking system stages these tumors based on activity: Latent, Active, and Aggressive.

Bone tumors are classified as benign or malignant. Benign tumors include osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma, chondroma, enchondroma, non-ossifying fibroma, and aneurysmal bone cysts. Malignant tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma management involves chemotherapy and surgery.

Enneking's classification of bone tumors categorizes them by grade (low/high), compartment (intraosseous/extraosseous), and metastatic status (none, metastasis present). This framework guides treatment strategies, aiming for wide or radical resection based on tumor biology and extent.

Osteoblastoma is a locally aggressive benign tumor, typically affecting young adults with long-standing pain. It can mimic malignant lesions and may occur in long bones, pelvis, or the spine. Management is typically surgical due to its locally aggressive nature, involving marginal resection or curettage and grafting.

Osteofibrous dysplasia is a benign tumor affecting the tibia, often associated with trisomy. It presents with anterior or anterolateral bowing and may cause pseudoarthrosis. Management is non-operative if asymptomatic, with intralesional curettage and grafting for symptomatic lesions.

Osteoid Osteoma is a benign tumor characterized by a <1cm nidus with a surrounding lucent ring and sclerotic rim, often causing night pain responsive to NSAIDs. It is most common in the proximal femur, tibial diaphysis, and posterior spinal elements. Management includes NSAIDs, RF ablation, or surgical excision if other treatments fail.

Tumor-like lesions of bone include fibrous dysplasia (abnormal bone formation, possibly related to gene mutations, characterized by "alphabet soup" appearance on XR), osteofibrous dysplasia (affecting the tibia), and Paget's disease of bone (disordered osteoclast/osteoblast activity). Benign tumors like bone islands (enostoses) are asymptomatic lesions of failed ossification.

Bone tumors are classified by Enneking based on grade, compartment, and metastatic status. Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic, post-radiotherapy, and Paget's. Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, de-differentiated), clear cell, mesenchymal, and post-radiotherapy. Histologic features are key for diagnosis.

Paraosteal osteomas are rare, benign, self-limiting tumors growing on the bone surface, similar to osteochondromas. They are histologically mature lamellar bone and can be associated with Gardener's syndrome. Bone islands (enostoses) are benign, asymptomatic lesions representing focal failure of endochondral ossification, often found incidentally in the proximal femur.

Osteopikilosis is a hereditary autosomal dominant condition causing hundreds of small bone islands, often around joints. Enchondromas are benign intramedullary tumors of hyaline cartilage that can rarely transform into low-grade chondrosarcomas, typically occurring in the hands and long bones. Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions with a chondroid matrix.

Chondromyxoid Fibromas are rare, benign, locally aggressive tumors with a metaphyseal lytic lesion. They can mimic other lesions like ABC or GCT. Management involves intralesional curettage and grafting, with a 10% recurrence rate. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors, often asymptomatic, with characteristic "jailbar" appearance on X-ray. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children and adolescents, representing excessive osteoclast activity during metaphyseal remodeling.

Giant Cell Tumours (GCT) are benign but locally aggressive, typically affecting women aged 30-50. They often present with short-history pain and pathologic fractures. Imaging shows an eccentric lytic lesion, and they are classified according to Campanacci on X-ray. Management involves intralesional curettage and grafting, with a 15% recurrence rate.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas are characterized by a nidus and night pain, managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and typically treated with marginal resection. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions of failed endochondral ossification.

Osteopikilosis involves multiple bone islands, often associated with other conditions. Enchondromas are benign intramedullary tumors of hyaline cartilage that can rarely undergo malignant transformation. Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal lesions managed with intralesional curettage and grafting.

Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors, often asymptomatic, with characteristic "jailbar" appearance on X-ray. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children and adolescents. Giant Cell Tumours are benign but locally aggressive, typically affecting women aged 30-50, and are managed with intralesional curettage and grafting.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma (most common, affecting young adults/children, treated with chemotherapy and surgery), chondrosarcoma (cartilage tumors, grade-dependent prognosis), fibrosarcoma (similar to osteosarcoma but no osteoid), chordoma (arising from notochord remnants, midline spine), lymphoma of bone (B-cell lymphoma), multiple myeloma (plasma cell dyscrasia), and metastatic bone disease.

Osteosarcoma features include Codman's triangle and sunray spicules on X-ray, with management involving neo-adjuvant chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors. Fibrosarcomas are chemo-sensitive. Chordomas often occur in the sacrum and spine and require wide excision. Lymphoma of bone and multiple myeloma are systemic diseases treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

Multiple myeloma is the most common malignant bone tumor, predominantly affecting men over 50, particularly Black individuals. It arises from plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to abnormal protein production, osteoblast inhibition, and osteoclast stimulation. Clinical features include bone pain, pathologic fractures (especially spinal), renal failure, and hypercalcemia. Imaging reveals punched-out lytic lesions with no sclerotic rim, a 'pepper pot' skull appearance, and multi-site involvement. Bone scans are typically negative due to osteoblast inactivation.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically: osteogenic (Osteoid Osteoma, Osteoblastoma), chondrogenic (Chondroma, Enchondroma, Chondroblastoma), fibrogenic (Non-ossifying Fibroma, Desmoplastic Fibroma, Chondromyxoid Fibroma), cystic (Unicameral Bone Cyst, Aneurysmal Bone Cyst), and unknown origin (GCT, Langerhans cell histiocytosis). Osteoid Osteomas typically cause night pain relieved by NSAIDs and are managed with NSAIDs or RF ablation.

Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive benign tumors, often presenting with long-standing pain, and are managed surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas are benign intramedullary tumors that can rarely undergo malignant transformation. Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions.

Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal lesions. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic "jailbar" appearance on X-ray. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children and adolescents. Giant Cell Tumours are benign but locally aggressive, often presenting with pain and pathologic fractures.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma (most common, affects young patients, treated with chemotherapy and surgery), chondrosarcoma (grade-dependent prognosis), fibrosarcoma (similar to osteosarcoma but no osteoid), chordoma (midline spine tumors), lymphoma of bone (B-cell lymphoma), multiple myeloma (plasma cell disorder), and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma management involves neo-adjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery.

Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses. Fibrosarcomas are chemo-sensitive. Chordomas require wide excision. Lymphoma of bone and multiple myeloma are treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Metastatic bone disease spreads via Batson's venous plexus or hematogenous seeding, commonly affecting the spine, pelvis, and proximal long bones.

Imaging characteristics of metastatic bone disease vary with tumor type: lytic (lung, thyroid, kidney, GI), sclerotic (prostate, bladder), or mixed (breast). Pathologic fractures are common. Diagnostic workup includes history, examination, laboratory tests (LDH, Alk Phos, myeloma screen), and imaging (X-ray, bone scan, MRI, CT).

Malignant soft tissue tumors are called sarcomas and are classified by tissue of origin. They are more common in older patients and males. Worrying clinical features include rapid growth, pain, large size, and neurovascular symptoms. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma, radiotherapy for margins).

Synovial sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in young adults, associated with SYT gene abnormality and t(X;18) translocation. Clear cell sarcoma is a rare soft tissue sarcoma of the foot producing melanin. Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand and may be mistaken for benign lesions. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults and is chemo-sensitive.

Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood and is chemo-sensitive. Leiomyosarcoma is a smooth muscle tumor. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells and may be associated with NF1 or NF2. Angiosarcoma is highly malignant, rare, and often requires amputation due to vascular involvement.

Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses. Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses. Imaging characteristics and diagnostic workup vary depending on the tumor type.

Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand and may be mistaken for benign lesions. MFH is common in older adults and is chemo-sensitive. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas typically cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children and adolescents. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Fibrosarcomas resemble osteosarcomas but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine and can metastasize late. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup depend on the suspected tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are called sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults and affects the foot, while clear cell sarcoma is also a soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand and may be mistaken for benign lesions. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexes, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.
Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting.

Bone tumors are classified as benign or malignant. Benign tumors include osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma, chondroma, enchondroma, non-ossifying fibroma, and aneurysmal bone cysts. Malignant tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Management strategies vary based on tumor type, grade, and location.

Malignant soft tissue tumors, or sarcomas, are classified by tissue of origin. They are more common in older patients and males, presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI is often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management involves wide local excision and adjuvant therapy, with prognosis varying by tumor type and grade.

Bone tumors are classified by Enneking (grade, compartment, metastasis) and by subtype (Osteosarcoma, Chondrosarcoma, etc.). Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic, and post-radiotherapy. Chondrosarcoma subtypes are intramedullary, de-differentiated, clear cell, mesenchymal, and post-radiotherapy. Prognosis correlates with grade and subtype.

Poor prognostic factors for osteosarcoma include high LDH/alkaline phosphatase, absence of anti-shock protein 90, pelvic location, pathologic fracture, poor tumor necrosis post-chemo, vascular invasion, recurrence, and metastases. Early detection and aggressive treatment are key.

Enneking's classification of bone tumors categorizes them by grade (low/high), compartment (intraosseous/extraosseous), and metastatic status. This framework dictates treatment, aiming for wide or radical resection to achieve oncologic control while preserving function where possible.

Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic), post-radiation, and Paget's disease-related. Intramedullary is most common, often around the knee. Prognosis varies by subtype, grade, and presence of metastases, with early diagnosis and multimodal treatment being crucial.

Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, de-differentiated, clear cell, mesenchymal), post-radiation, and Paget's related. Prognosis is strongly correlated with histological grade. De-differentiated chondrosarcoma has the worst prognosis, often requiring more aggressive treatment.

Bone tumors are classified by Enneking (grade, compartment, metastasis) and subtype (e.g., Osteosarcoma, Chondrosarcoma). Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic, and post-radiation. Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, de-differentiated, clear cell, and mesenchymal. Prognosis correlates with grade and subtype.

Poor prognostic factors for osteosarcoma include high LDH/alkaline phosphatase, absence of anti-shock protein 90, pelvic location, pathologic fracture, poor tumor necrosis post-chemo, vascular invasion, recurrence, and metastases. Early detection and aggressive treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

topics.topic: Acromioclavicular (AC) Joint Injury Classification and Management
topics.text: AC joint injuries are classified by Rockwood (Types I-VI) based on ligamentous disruption and displacement. Types I and II are typically managed nonoperatively. Type III management is controversial, with nonoperative treatment often favored for active individuals. Higher grades (IV-VI) usually require surgical intervention, including dynamic or static stabilization techniques, or sometimes distal clavicle excision or distal clavicle fracture fixation.

topics.topic: Acromioclavicular (AC) Joint Injury: Management and Complications
topics.text: AC joint injuries are managed based on Rockwood classification. Nonoperative treatment is common for Types I-III. Higher grades (IV-VI) often require surgery (e.g., coracoclavicular repair, hook plate, suture techniques) to restore stability. Complications of nonoperative treatment can include chronic AC joint arthritis, weakness, and cosmetic deformity. Surgical complications may involve hardware issues or nerve injury.

Clavicle fractures are classified by location (medial, midshaft, lateral) and pattern (simple, wedge, multifragmentary). The Allman and Neer classifications are traditional, while the Edinburgh Classification further subdivides shaft fractures by displacement and comminution. These classifications help guide treatment decisions, though therapeutic and prognostic value can be limited by the degree of displacement.

Clavicle fractures are common, especially in young males and older adults. Midshaft fractures are most frequent (66%), followed by lateral (25%) and medial (3%). The clavicle's anatomy, with its S-shape and minimal muscle attachments in the midshaft, makes it vulnerable. Associated injuries (e.g., neurovascular, scapulothoracic dissociation) must be assessed, especially in high-energy trauma. Most midshaft fractures heal well nonoperatively, but displaced fractures have higher nonunion rates and may benefit from surgery.

topics.topic: Clavicle Fracture: Postoperative Care and Complications
topics.text: Postoperative care involves sling immobilization for 2-3 weeks, followed by gradual range of motion and strengthening exercises. Complications include wound infection (reduced by layered closure), infraclavicular numbness (common, usually temporary), hardware prominence/irritation, refracture, and nonunion (higher with nonoperative treatment of displaced midshaft fractures). Malunion may require corrective osteotomy if symptomatic.

topics.topic: Clavicle Fracture: Surgical Approaches and Fixation
topics.text: Surgical approaches to the clavicle include the deltopectoral (anterior), transdeltoid (lateral), and posterior approaches. Fixation commonly uses plates (LC-DCP, LCP, reconstruction plates) applied superiorly or anteriorly, or intramedullary fixation with elastic nails (ESIN). MIPO techniques are also used. Implant choice depends on fracture pattern, bone quality, and surgeon preference, with locking plates offering enhanced stability, especially in osteoporotic bone.

Absolute indications for surgery include open fractures, impending skin perforation, concomitant ipsilateral upper limb injuries, floating shoulder/elbow, polytrauma, neurovascular injuries, multiple rib fractures with chest deformity, significant displacement (>2.5 cm), and scapular winging. Relative indications involve displaced fractures, malunions, or nonunions, requiring careful consideration of risks versus benefits.
Fracture of the clavicle is the most common musculoskeletal birth injury. It is the first bone in the body to ossify (at 5 weeks gestation) and the last to fuse (medial epiphysis at 25 years of age).

Neer's classification of clavicle fractures categorizes them by location: Type 1 (middle third), Type 2 (distal third, further subdivided by CC ligament integrity and displacement), and Type 3 (proximal third). Type 2 fractures are further subtyped based on displacement and involvement of the conoid and trapezoid ligaments, influencing treatment.

Glenoid fractures are classified by Ideberg (modified by Goss) into types based on location and pattern: Type 1A (anterior rim), 1B (posterior rim), Type 2 (transverse exiting inferiorly), Type 3 (transverse exiting medial to coracoid), Type 4 (transverse exiting medial border), Type 5 (combination of 2 and 4), and Type 6 (comminuted).

Snyder's classification of SLAP tears describes types based on labral and biceps anchor involvement: Type 1 (fraying), Type 2 (unstable biceps anchor), Type 3 (bucket-handle labral tear, intact biceps), Type 4 (bucket-handle tear extending into biceps tendon). Types 5-7 describe combinations with other tears or capsular involvement, guiding debridement or repair.

Fractures of the proximal humerus in children, particularly in younger age groups, have significant remodeling potential, allowing for acceptance of considerable angulation and displacement if growth potential remains. Nonoperative management is generally preferred. However, displaced fractures, especially those with malrotation or instability, may require operative intervention. Techniques like closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation or elastic stable intramedullary nailing (ESIN) are commonly used. For proximal humerus fractures in older children or those with surgical indications, specialized plates like the PHILOS or PHN offer stable fixation.

topics.topic: Proximal Humerus Fractures: Anatomy and Blood Supply
topics.text: The proximal humerus has a complex anatomy with the humeral head, surgical neck, greater tuberosity, and lesser tuberosity. The blood supply, particularly to the humeral head, is vulnerable, with the posterior circumflex humeral artery playing a significant role. Injury to the blood supply can lead to avascular necrosis (AVN) of the humeral head, impacting fracture healing and prognosis.

Proximal humerus fractures are classified using the AO/OTA system (11A-C) based on fracture location and complexity, and the Neer classification, which categorizes fractures based on the displacement of four main parts (head, shaft, greater tuberosity, lesser tuberosity). The Hertel classification (LEGO) further details fragmentation patterns. These classifications guide treatment decisions and predict outcomes.

topics.topic: Proximal Humerus Fractures: Epidemiology and Evaluation
topics.text: Proximal humeral fractures are common, especially in the elderly due to falls, with incidence rising in this demographic. Most are minimally displaced and treated nonoperatively. High-energy trauma in younger patients causes more severe, displaced fractures. Evaluation involves X-rays and often CT scans for complex patterns, with crucial assessment of neurovascular status, particularly the axillary nerve.

Neer's classification of proximal humerus fractures categorizes them by displacement of the four main parts: head, shaft, greater tuberosity, and lesser tuberosity. Fractures with displacement of two or more parts are considered more severe and often require surgical intervention to restore anatomical alignment and prevent complications like AVN or stiffness.

topics.topic: Proximal Humerus Fractures: Postoperative Care and Complications
topics.text: Postoperative care involves sling immobilization and early rehabilitation with pendulum exercises, progressing to active range of motion. Complications include screw penetration, malunion (especially varus), AVN of the humeral head, rotator cuff injury, stiffness, and nerve palsy (axillary nerve). Reverse shoulder arthroplasty is increasingly used for severe fractures in the elderly due to its more predictable outcomes.

topics.topic: Proximal Humerus Fractures: Surgical Indications and Techniques
topics.text: Surgical indications for proximal humerus fractures include displaced fractures (>1 cm displacement or >45 angulation), head-splitting fractures, neurovascular injuries, open fractures, unstable fracture-dislocations, and those in polytrauma patients. Treatment options range from nonoperative management to IM nailing, MIPO, or arthroplasty (hemiarthroplasty or reverse shoulder arthroplasty), with implant choice depending on fracture pattern, bone quality, and patient factors.

Surgical techniques for proximal humerus fractures vary: K-wires and tension band wiring are used for simple tuberosity fractures. Plates (LC-DCP, LCP) with screws are common for displaced fractures, often requiring careful contouring. IM nailing is an option for certain patterns, especially in polytrauma. Arthroplasty (hemi or reverse) is reserved for severe fractures, particularly in osteoporotic elderly patients or those with irreparable rotator cuff pathology.

topics.topic: Scapula Fractures: Incidence, Mechanism, and Classification
topics.text: Scapula fractures are associated with other injuries in 80% of cases, including rib, clavicle, lung contusion, and spine fractures. The mechanism varies: falls onto the hand can cause scapular spine, glenoid, and intra-articular fractures, while direct high-energy trauma typically leads to body fractures. Fractures are classified by anatomical location: body, spine, neck, glenoid, coracoid, and acromion. The Ideberg classification, modified by Goss, describes glenoid fractures into seven types based on rim involvement and fracture pattern.

topics.topic: Diagnosis and Management of Scapula Fractures
topics.text: Diagnosis involves X-rays (axillary, AP, scapula Y, and Stryker notch views), fine-cut CT, and chest X-ray. Management prioritizes ABCs, ruling out and treating associated injuries, and supporting chest and spinal injuries. Compartment syndrome is rare but possible, indicated by the Comolli sign (hematoma over the scapula). Non-operative treatment with a broad arm sling and early shoulder mobilization is common. Operative indications include displaced glenoid rim fractures (>25% size), incongruent or unstable shoulders, articular incongruity (>5mm), medial displacement of the neck (>1cm), significant angulation (>40 degrees), or a 'floating shoulder' (disruption of the superior shoulder suspensory complex).

Anterior rim fractures are best addressed via an extensile Deltopectoral (DP) approach. Posterior glenoid or neck/spine fractures are treated with an extended Judet approach, utilizing the interval between the infraspinatus and teres minor muscles.

Scapulothoracic dissociation is a rare but severe injury, typically caused by high-energy motor vehicle accidents (90%) involving traction injury to the arm. The scapulothoracic articulation is avulsed, often with a concomitant clavicle fracture or ACJ disruption, effectively resulting in a traumatic internal forequarter amputation. It is associated with a 10% mortality rate and high incidences of complete plexus and vascular injuries. Diagnosis is aided by AP X-rays showing increased distance from the midline and associated clavicle fractures. Management decisions regarding reduction, angiography, scapulothoracic fusion, or primary amputation are determined by the severity of plexus and vascular injuries. Outcomes are generally poor, significantly influenced by the presence of a complete plexus injury.

SLAP (Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior) tears are uncommon, accounting for approximately 5% of shoulder injuries. They involve disruption of the superior labrum, which is more loosely adherent to the glenoid than the anterior-inferior labrum. The biceps tendon inserts into the superior labrum, and variations in this insertion can mimic pathology. Diagnosis is challenging and may require MR arthrography.

topics.topic: Femur Shaft Fractures: Radial Nerve Injury (Typo, should be Humeral)
Humeral Shaft Fractures: Anatomy and Nerve Injury Risk
topics.text: The radial nerve crosses the posterior aspect of the humeral shaft, particularly vulnerable in the spiral groove in the distal third. Radial nerve palsy is a common complication of midshaft and distal humeral shaft fractures, particularly those caused by rotation or direct trauma. Most palsies are neurapraxic and recover spontaneously, but surgical exploration may be needed if there is no recovery or associated vascular injury.

topics.topic: Humeral Shaft Fractures: Anatomy and Non-Surgical Management
topics.text: The radial nerve crosses the humeral midpoint, approximately 14cm proximal to the lateral epicondyle, within the spiral groove. Non-surgical management is common, accepting some deformity such as up to 30 degrees of coronal plane varus (worse as it reduces shoulder abduction) and 20 degrees of sagittal plane angulation, along with minimal shortening. Treatment involves co-aptation splinting, followed by a functional brace after one week, with serial tightening.

topics.topic: Humeral Shaft Fractures: Complications and Prognosis
topics.text: Complications include radial nerve palsy (often temporary), malunion (particularly varus deformity), nonunion (low overall, but higher with open fractures or poor technique), and infection. Most fractures heal well, but malunion can affect shoulder function and cosmesis. Surgical treatment aims to restore alignment, stability, and promote early motion to optimize functional outcomes.

topics.topic: Humeral Shaft Fractures: Epidemiology and Management
topics.text: Humeral shaft fractures are common, often caused by direct trauma. Most are treated nonoperatively with functional bracing, as the shoulder's range of motion tolerates some deformity. Surgical indications include open fractures, vascular/nerve injuries, significant displacement, nonunion, pathological fractures, and inability to maintain reduction. MIPO techniques and IM nailing are common surgical options.

topics.topic: Humeral Shaft Fractures: Surgical Approaches and Fixation
topics.text: Surgical approaches include anterior (deltopectoral, anterolateral split) and posterior routes. Fixation options include plating (DCP, LC-DCP, LCP) and IM nailing. MIPO techniques are increasingly used to minimize soft-tissue disruption. Plates are preferred for fractures with articular extension or malunion, while IM nails are suitable for diaphyseal fractures, especially in polytrauma or when nonunion is a concern.

topics.topic: Humeral Shaft Fractures: Surgical Management and Fixation
topics.text: Surgery is generally indicated for inability to maintain closed reduction within acceptable parameters, open fractures, simple transverse or short oblique patterns, polytrauma, or floating elbows. Surgery typically results in lower malunion and non-union rates. Fixation options include external fixation (for polytrauma or contamination), plating (requiring 8 cortices on each side of the fracture, or 6 with good lag screws, or bridge plating considering working length), and IM nailing (though associated with shoulder pain and cuff damage). Meta-analyses suggest plating may have a lower overall complication rate than nailing.

topics.topic: Radial Nerve Palsy Associated with Humeral Shaft Fractures
topics.text: There is an 11% risk of radial nerve palsy with humeral shaft fractures, increasing to 24% for distal third fractures, particularly in spiral and transverse patterns. Spontaneous recovery occurs in about 70% within a mean of 7 weeks, though it can take up to 6 months. EMG at 6 weeks is recommended if no recovery is observed, with repeat at 3 months. Exploration should be considered if there's no activity by 3 months, or if the palsy occurs after reduction in a Holstein-Lewis fracture pattern (though the benefit is not definitively proven).

Workup for non-union should identify contributing factors like smoking or infection. Treatment typically involves ORIF with bone grafting and compression plating. Compression plating alone may suffice for hypertrophic non-unions.

Distal radius fractures are common injuries, particularly in elderly individuals due to osteoporosis and falls. They can be extraarticular or intraarticular. The type of fracture, displacement, and associated injuries guide the treatment, which may range from casting to operative fixation with plates and screws.

Distal radius fractures are common injuries, particularly in elderly individuals due to osteoporosis and falls. They can be extraarticular or intraarticular. The type of fracture, displacement, and associated injuries guide the treatment, which may range from casting to operative fixation with plates and screws.

topics.topic: Distal Radius Fractures: Classification and Evaluation
topics.text: Distal radius fractures are common, especially in the elderly. They are classified by AO/OTA (C-type for articular) and Frykman systems. Evaluation involves X-rays (AP, lateral, oblique) and often CT for intra-articular involvement. Assessment includes reduction quality, stability, and associated carpal injuries. Careful assessment is crucial for determining the need for surgical intervention.

topics.topic: Distal Radius Fractures: Nonoperative vs. Operative Treatment
topics.text: Nonoperative treatment with closed reduction and casting is suitable for stable, undisplaced fractures. Operative treatment, including closed reduction with percutaneous pinning or open reduction with internal fixation (plates, screws), is indicated for unstable fractures, those with significant displacement, articular incongruity, or associated neurovascular compromise. MIPO techniques are increasingly used.

topics.topic: Distal Radius Fractures: Surgical Techniques and Complications
topics.text: Surgical techniques involve open reduction with anatomical restoration of the articular surface and fixation with plates (e.g., LCP, reconstruction plates) and screws. MIPO approaches minimize soft-tissue disruption. Complications include stiffness, malunion, nonunion, complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), and hardware issues. Rehabilitation is crucial for optimizing functional recovery, regaining grip strength, and restoring wrist motion.

Forearm shaft fractures are classified by AO/OTA based on location (radius or ulna) and morphology (simple, wedge, multifragmentary). This classification system aids in understanding the fracture pattern, predicting associated injuries, and guiding treatment strategies, from nonoperative management to ORIF with plates or nails.

Complications of forearm shaft fractures include nerve palsy (radial, posterior interosseous, median, ulnar), compartment syndrome, synostosis (radius-ulna union), nonunion, malunion (especially rotational deformity), and hardware issues. Careful surgical technique, appropriate implant selection, and diligent postoperative rehabilitation are crucial to minimize these risks and optimize functional outcomes.

topics.topic: Forearm Shaft Fractures: Monteggia and Galeazzi Injuries
topics.text: Monteggia fractures involve an ulna shaft fracture with proximal radial head dislocation, typically requiring ORIF of the ulna and often closed reduction/splinting or pinning of the radial head. Galeazzi fractures involve a radial shaft fracture with DRUJ dislocation, mandating operative fixation of the radius to reduce the DRUJ. Essex-Lopresti lesions combine elbow and distal radioulnar joint disruptions, requiring complex reconstruction.

topics.topic: Forearm Shaft Fractures: Surgical Management Principles
topics.text: Surgical management aims for anatomical reduction and stable fixation to restore forearm rotation and function. Plates are the preferred fixation for most adult forearm fractures. Approaches are typically separate for the radius (Henry or posterolateral) and ulna (posterior subcutaneous) to avoid damaging neurovascular structures and prevent radioulnar synostosis. Early mobilization is encouraged postoperatively.

Capitellar fractures are classified by Bryan & Morrey into Type 1 (complete, minimal trochlear extension), Type 2 (osteochondritis dissecans), Type 3 (comminuted, compressed), and Type 4 (complete with significant trochlear extension). These classifications help guide treatment, particularly surgical fixation versus non-operative management.

topics.topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Coronoid Process Fractures (Morrey & O'Driscoll)
topics.text: Coronoid process fractures are classified by Morrey based on height (<2mm, >2mm) and by O'Driscoll based on location and extent (tip, rim, body, anteromedial basal fracture). The latter classification further subtypes rim and body fractures, aiding in understanding the injury's severity and guiding treatment, especially in the context of associated elbow instability.

Monteggia fractures involve a fracture of the ulna with associated dislocation of the radial head. Bado's classification describes Type 1 (anterior radial head dislocation), Type 2 (posterior), Type 3 (lateral), and Type 4 (associated radial shaft fracture). Type 2a, with angulation and disc extrusion, is a severe injury despite a benign appearance.

Radial head fractures are classified by Mason into Type 1 (undisplaced), Type 2 (marginal fracture, displaced), Type 3 (displaced, comminuted), and Type 4 (fracture with elbow dislocation). This classification influences treatment decisions, with non-operative management for Type 1 and surgical intervention for Types 2-4.

Radial head and neck fractures are common elbow injuries, often associated with elbow dislocations. They can be caused by direct trauma or repetitive stress. Treatment depends on the displacement and associated injuries.

Radial head and neck fractures are common elbow injuries, often associated with elbow dislocations. They can be caused by direct trauma or repetitive stress. Treatment depends on the displacement and associated injuries.

topics.topic: Radial Head and Neck Fractures: Mason Classification
topics.text: Radial head fractures are classified by Mason (Type 1-4) based on displacement and association with elbow dislocation. Type 1 (undisplaced) and Type 2 (marginal, displaced) are often treated nonoperatively. Type 3 (comminuted, displaced) and Type 4 (with elbow dislocation) usually require operative intervention, such as ORIF or radial head replacement, to restore stability and function.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Radial Head (Mason) and Coronoid Process (Morrey/O'Driscoll) Fractures
topics.text: Radial head fractures are classified by Mason (Type 1-4) based on displacement and association with elbow dislocation.
