Psoriatic arthropathy (PsA) affects patients with psoriasis and typically involves distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, nail changes, and prominent enthesitis. Radiographic findings can include pencil-in-cup deformities and small joint ankylosis.

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy that occurs secondary to genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections (Chlamydia, Shigella, Salmonella, Campylobacter). It typically affects the knee and can involve enthesitis and spondylolitis. Extra-articular manifestations, such as severe conjunctivitis and urethritis, are key to diagnosis. Management is primarily medical, with supportive therapy for the self-limiting condition.

Reactive arthritis, formerly known as Reiter syndrome, is an inflammatory arthritis that follows an infection elsewhere in the body. The classic triad includes conjunctivitis, urethritis, and oligoarticular arthritis, though not all features are always present.

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are RF-negative arthritides and include Ankylosing Spondylitis, Psoriatic Arthritis, Enteropathic Arthritis, Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's syndrome), and Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is associated with psoriasis and HLA B27 positivity, often affecting the hands with dactylitis and nail pitting. Enteropathic arthritis is linked to IBD, primarily affecting the lower limbs and spine.

Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism leading to intra-articular uric acid crystal deposition, causing pain, inflammation, and arthropathy. It affects 80% of men and older adults, often mono-articular, commonly involving the thumb IPJ, big toe IPJ, and ankle. Flare-ups are triggered by increased metabolic activity (alcohol, purines, thiazide diuretics). Aspiration revealing negatively birefringent crystals is diagnostic.

Calcium hydroxyapatite crystal deposition disease involves the abnormal accumulation of apatite crystals, the primary crystal of normal bone, in areas of tissue damage or in hypercalcemic states. It is associated with bursitis, synovitis, and degenerative joint disease.

Pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), is characterized by intra-articular deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals, causing acute inflammatory arthritis that can mimic septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals. Management is symptomatic with NSAIDs, rest, and activity modification.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy is caused by calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition in the joint, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee being most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting the Fibrillin gene, leading to tall stature, spindly hands, joint hypermobility, scoliosis, dural ectasia, protrusio acetabuli, and planovalgus feet. Cardiothoracic manifestations include pectus excavatum and aortic root dilatation. Management involves referral for ECHO, genetic counseling, and aggressive scoliosis treatment.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is a disorder of collagen (COL5A1 or COL5A2 mutation) causing joint hypermobility and excessive skin laxity. Clinical features include fragile, lax, easily scarred skin, global joint hypermobility with recurrent dislocations (especially shoulder), and severe kyphoscoliosis. Management involves aggressive treatment of scoliosis and potential surgery for protrusio acetabuli and planovalgus feet.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is caused by mutations in COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, affecting normal bone formation. Bones are brittle and prone to multiple fractures, with olecranon apophyseal avulsion fractures being common. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, basilar invagination, and tooth defects. Management can be non-surgical (genetic counseling, bisphosphonates, growth hormone, bone marrow transplant) or surgical (fracture fixation, scoliosis treatment).

Scleroderma is a systemic disease causing sclerotic changes, with the main orthopaedic manifestation being in the hands, including erosion of distal phalanx tufts, soft tissue calcification, DIPJ and PIPJ contractures, Raynaud's phenomenon, and skin ulceration. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune systemic condition affecting young women, with 95% being ANA and anti-DNA positive. Clinical features include hand and small joint involvement with ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation, joint laxity, and osteonecrosis (secondary to steroid use). Extra-articular features include Raynaud's and facial butterfly rash. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and joint fusions.

Type III is in granulation tissue and associated with Dupuytren's contracture. Type IV is in basement membranes.

Patellofemoral joint mechanics influence tracking and contact pressures. Ligaments (ACL, PCL, collaterals) provide static and dynamic stability.

The tibia is cut perpendicular to the mechanical axis to prevent uneven loading of bearing surfaces. To achieve a rectangular flexion gap, the AP femoral cuts are made with 3 degrees greater external rotation than the epicondylar axis. The distal femoral cut (valgus cut angle) creates a rectangular extension gap, typically set at 5-7 degrees valgus.

The PCL prevents flexion instability by opposing excessive posterior tibial translation. It also permits physiologic femoral rollback, preventing impingement and allowing greater flexion. PCL retaining designs offer advantages in maintaining normal kinematics and femoral rollback.

Femoral rotation is critical for creating a rectangular flexion gap and proper patella tracking. The epicondylar axis is a reliable landmark, and Whitesides line (deepest femoral sulcus to deepest trochlea) is perpendicular to the femoral axis of rotation. Posterior condyles are parallel to the rotation axis.

Ligament releases for varus deformity are performed from the tibia (osteophytes, deep MCL, PMC & semimembranosus, sup MCL, PCL) and femur (osteophytes, lateral capsule, ITB, popliteus, LCL, lateral head gastrocnemius). For fixed flexion, osteophytes are addressed, the distal femoral cut is increased, and PCL recession may be performed.

Patellofemoral joint management is mandatory in TKR for inflammatory arthritis, as the PCL is affected by the disease process, potentially leading to greater instability due to soft tissue factors. Implant types include dome (most common, eliminates rotational issues), anatomic (better conformity but less positioning tolerance), and mobile bearing (allows conformity and reduces stress but has issues with poly spin out).

TKR design principles focus on restoring normal knee biomechanics, including alignment, joint line, and ligament balance. Modern TKRs aim for normal femoral rollback, with PCL retaining or substituting designs. Mobile bearing knees offer conformity but may have poly spin out issues. Causes of TKR failure include osteolysis, aseptic loosening, wear, instability, and infection.

topics.topic: Total Knee Replacement In Specific Situations
topics.text: TKR after previous high tibial osteotomy (HTO) or patellectomy can present challenges. HTO may result in worse TKR outcomes and more difficult lateral closing wedge osteotomies. Previous patellectomy leads to reduced quadriceps power, potentially causing flexion instability and maltracking. Neuropathic arthropathy (e.g., Charcot) generally has worse outcomes, requiring careful management and potential grafting.

Alterations in the Q angle or malrotation of components can cause patellofemoral maltracking and impingement pain. These issues can be minimized by lateralizing the patella button or femoral component. Patella baja, caused by elevated joint line or excessive distal femoral resection, can lead to patellar tendon shortening and impingement.

Navigation in TKR is beneficial for addressing pre-operative femoral or tibial deformities and has been shown to improve the consistency of recreating correct mechanical axes in primary TKR, although its correlation with improved clinical outcomes is not yet established.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Order of Soft Tissue Releases in Total Knee Replacement (TKR)
topics.text: The order of soft tissue releases in TKR depends on the deformity. For varus, releases proceed from osteophytes to the medial capsule, deep MCL, PCL, and sequential superficial MCL release. For valgus, it involves lateral capsule, ITB/popliteus, LCL, and posterolateral capsule. For flexion contractures, posterior capsule, PCL, and tibial plateau/femur adjustments are performed.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: TKR Soft Tissue Releases
topics.text: Soft tissue releases in TKR depend on the deformity. Varus correction involves releasing osteophytes, medial capsule, deep MCL, PCL, and sequential superficial MCL. Valgus correction addresses lateral capsule, ITB/popliteus, LCL, and posterolateral capsule. Flexion contractures require posterior capsule/PCL release and tibial slope adjustments.

Elbow replacements can be linked or unlinked. Unlinked designs rely on collateral ligaments and articular congruity, which are technically challenging to balance. Linked replacements act as 'sloppy hinges' with 6 degrees of freedom, allowing 7-10 degrees of varus-valgus laxity, which reduces bone implant stress and prevents premature loosening or fracture.

topics.topic: Hemiarthroplasty for Proximal Humerus Fractures: Patient and Fracture Factors
topics.text: Hemiarthroplasty is indicated for low-demand patients, generally over 75 years old unless very fit, and more commonly in females due to osteoporotic bone. Fracture factors favoring hemiarthroplasty include head-split fractures, delayed fracture-dislocations, and initial varus malalignment greater than 20 degrees where anatomical reduction of the medial hinge cannot be achieved. It is also a salvage option for failed ORIF, AVN, non-union, or malunion.

topics.topic: Key Factors for Successful Hemiarthroplasty of the Proximal Humerus
topics.text: Successful hemiarthroplasty relies on accurate tuberosity reduction and healing, with the greater tuberosity positioned 10-15 mm from the top of the prosthesis. Humeral head height should not be too proud to avoid tuberosity detachment or too short, which compromises cuff mechanics. The top of the pectoralis major tendon should be approximately 5.6 cm below the top of the head, and the tuberosity should be 10-15 mm below the head. Correct humeral head version is crucial, aiming for 20-30 degrees to prevent posterior instability; excessive retroversion is a common mistake.

topics.topic: Complications and Outcomes of Proximal Humerus Hemiarthroplasty
topics.text: Complications include dislocation, glenoid erosion, iatrogenic fracture, tuberosity non-union or malunion, and poor cuff function (especially with pre-existing cuff disease). Best outcomes are achieved when hemiarthroplasty is performed early (<2 weeks), as a primary procedure (not salvage), and when the tuberosities heal in an anatomical position. Expected outcomes include 90 degrees of abduction, 30 degrees of external rotation, and 100 degrees of forward flexion.

First-generation ankle replacements (1970s) were all cemented and either constrained or unconstrained. They failed due to subsidence from cementation in soft bone and loosening at the bone-implant interface. Second-generation designs are semi-constrained with three components, allowing sliding and better conformity, and tend to be uncemented with reduced subsidence and loosening. Indications include OA and rheumatoid arthritis in low-demand elderly patients.

Periprosthetic fractures are more common around the knee than the hip, with distal femur fractures being more frequent. Risk factors include osteoporosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and immunosuppression. Classification systems (Vancouver, Felix) help categorize fractures and guide management, which can be non-operative for stable, undisplaced fractures or surgical for unstable or displaced ones.

Periprosthetic fractures, particularly acetabular fractures, can occur intra-operatively (due to bone quality, impaction, or component issues) or post-operatively (due to trauma, infection, or loosening). Management depends on fracture displacement, component stability, extent, and bone stock. Femoral fractures are influenced by bone quality, stem design, and intra-operative factors like excessive femoral bow.

topics.topic: Periprosthetic Femur Fractures: Classification and Management
topics.text: Periprosthetic fractures occur around existing hip or knee arthroplasty implants. They are classified by Vancouver (hip) or Schenk (knee) systems based on location and implant stability. Management depends on fracture type, implant stability, bone quality, and patient factors, ranging from nonoperative treatment to revision arthroplasty, IF, or bone grafting. Early weight bearing is generally encouraged if fixation is stable.

Tribology studies friction and wear. Polyethylene's strength is influenced by molecular weight, cross-linking, crystallinity, manufacturing, and sterilization. UHMWPE's properties are based on increased chain length, number of chains, and amorphous areas, leading to strength and wear resistance. Cross-linking enhances wear resistance but can reduce fatigue resistance and fracture toughness.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Coefficients of Friction of Articulations
topics.text: Native knee and hip joints have very low coefficients of friction (0.005-0.01). Metal-on-polyethylene articulations are around 0.02, while metal-on-metal articulations have a significantly higher coefficient (0.8), contributing to higher wear rates.

Wear is the progressive loss of bearing material due to mechanical or chemical action. It has four modes: normal articulation, articulating vs. non-articulating surfaces, third-body wear, and wear from non-articulating surfaces rubbing. Mechanisms of wear include abrasive, adhesive, and fatigue processes. Wear is accelerated by factors like low joint conformity, thin polyethylene, malalignment, and subsurface faults.

Catastrophic wear in Total Knee Replacement (TKR) is distinct from long-term wear from submicron particles and is influenced by polyethylene thickness, manufacturing, sterilization, articular geometry, and sagittal plane kinematics. Minimum acceptable polyethylene thickness is 8mm, with thinner components having lower yield strength. Flatter polyethylene leading to decreased congruency and higher contact pressures causes accelerated wear, such as edge loading and fatigue failure.

Femoral component offset is advantageous as it increases the abductor lever arm. However, increasing neck length instead of prosthetic design can transfer stress to the implant tip and medial cement mantle, potentially leading to failure. Fixation methods include uncemented, cemented (composite beam), and cemented with uncemented implant interface (taper slip stem). Uncemented and composite beam designs have similar mechanical stresses at the cement-bone interface.

Bearing surfaces for older patients typically use metal on plastic, with well-produced and sterilized polyethylene. For younger patients, other options might be considered. Taper slip stems have different properties at the cement-bone interface, with low shear, minimal tensile stress, and high compressive stress due to cement's viscoelastic properties.

Friction is the resistance to sliding between two bodies in contact, influenced by surface adherence and fluid viscosity. Three laws of friction describe the relationship between frictional force, coefficient of friction, and applied load. Frictional wear is proportional to sliding distance. Asperities, or surface projections, contribute to roughness and friction.

PE sterilization methods include oxidation (weakening PE) and irradiation (cross-linking). Oxidized PE is weaker and more prone to wear, particularly in the subsurface white band. Highly cross-linked UHMWPE, produced by prolonged irradiation, offers improved strength and wear resistance. Direct compression molding is the preferred method of polyethylene manufacturing.

TKR after previous HTO or patellectomy presents challenges. HTO can lead to worse outcomes and more difficult procedures. Previous patellectomy compromises quadriceps power. Neuropathic arthropathy generally has worse outcomes. Management of bone loss involves classification and reconstructive options like impaction grafting, augments, and cages.

Periprosthetic fractures can occur around knee replacements, with distal femur fractures being more common. Risk factors for distal femur fractures include osteoporosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and immunosuppression. Management depends on fracture characteristics and patient factors, with non-operative treatment for stable, undisplaced fractures.

Charnley's principles for THA focused on minimizing JRF and friction. Acetabular cup implantation aims for the subchondral plate without excessive medialization. Femoral component offset is advantageous for abductor lever arm but can increase stress on the implant tip if neck length is increased. Fixation methods include uncemented and cemented stems.

TKR design principles focus on restoring normal knee biomechanics, including alignment, joint line, and ligament balance. Modern TKRs aim for normal femoral rollback, with PCL retaining or substituting designs. Mobile bearing knees offer conformity but can have poly spin out issues. Causes of TKR failure include osteolysis, aseptic loosening, wear, instability, and infection.

The knee's biomechanics involve condylar and saddle joints. Tibial plateau slope and varus/valgus alignment are important for stability. Femoral rollback during flexion is crucial for normal knee motion. Patellofemoral joint mechanics influence tracking and contact pressures. Ligaments like the ACL and PCL provide static and dynamic stability.

Knee biomechanics involve condylar and saddle joints. Tibial plateau slope and varus/valgus alignment are important for stability. Femoral rollback during flexion is crucial for normal knee motion. Patellofemoral joint mechanics influence tracking and contact pressures. Ligaments like the ACL and PCL provide static and dynamic stability.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities or weakness, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, cosmetic appeal, durability, washability, comfort, and freedom from pressure areas. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, total contact, and kinaesthetic reminders.

Pre-operative assessment for successful wound healing involves evaluating nutrition (low albumin, lymphocyte count, transferrin), vascularity (ABPI, transcutaneous oxygen tension), and planning myoplastic or myodesis techniques for muscle and bone management. General technical points include clean nerve transection, beveled bone ends, avoiding non-absorbable sutures, adequate scar formation, and appropriate stump shape.

topics.topic: Amputations: Load Transfer and Stump Healing Prerequisites
topics.text: Load transfer to the prosthetic socket can be direct (end-bearing stumps like Syme's or through-knee) or indirect (total contact for long bone amputations). Indirect transfer requires specific joint flexion (10 degrees at the knee for trans-tibial, 10 degrees adduction/flexion at the hip for transfemoral). Prerequisites for stump healing include adequate nutrition, vascularity (ischaemic index minimum 0.5, transcutaneous oxygen >40 mmHg), and good blood oxygenation (Hb >10).

topics.topic: Amputations: Metabolic Cost and Soft Tissue Envelope
topics.text: The metabolic cost of amputation increases with more proximal levels and is inversely proportional to the length of the stump or the number of functional joints. A good soft tissue envelope, ideally with a mobile muscle mass and full-thickness skin, is crucial for prosthesis fit, reducing shear stress, and preventing skin breakdown.

A prosthesis consists of several key parts: the socket (interface with the residual limb), suspension (attachment method), struts (restore length), articulations (replace joint function), and the terminal device (cosmetic or functional hand/foot). The terminal device can be passively cosmetic or actively controlled via cables, struts, or myoelectric signals.

topics.topic: Factors Negatively Influencing Amputation Stump Healing
topics.text: Several factors can impair amputation stump healing, including low serum albumin (<3.5 g/dL), low lymphocyte count (<1500/mm), low serum transferrin, low ABPI (<0.45), low transcutaneous oxygen saturation (<20 mmHg), and Hb <10 g/dL. These indicate poor nutritional status, peripheral vascular disease, or anemia.

Ideal amputation levels are chosen to maximize function and prosthetic fitting. For the forearm, the junction of the proximal 2/3 and distal 1/3 is preferred. The middle third of the humerus is ideal. For transtibial amputations, maintaining about 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity (relative to height) is crucial. The middle third of the femur is preferred for transfemoral amputations.

topics.topic: Pediatric Amputations and Amputation After Trauma
topics.text: Pediatric amputations are complicated by bony overgrowth within the stump due to open physes, often requiring revision. Amputation after trauma may offer better outcomes than limb salvage, with the MESS score being a consideration. For upper limb amputations, sensation and prehensile function are paramount, making salvage preferable if possible. Lower limb amputation considerations include plantar sensation loss, but caution is advised if it might be neuropraxia. Technical aspects include full-thickness skin flaps, avoiding dissection between tissue planes, stripping periosteum to minimize heterotopic bone, performing myodesis over myoplasty, securing muscles at resting length, and clean nerve cuts to minimize neuroma formation and phantom pain.

Prosthetic fitting should occur after wound healing, with mature scar and controlled edema/neuropathy. Early fitting (<30 days) generally yields better outcomes in the upper limb. Optimal amputation levels provide sufficient stump length for the prosthesis and its mechanism, considering factors like weight-bearing surface and suspension.

A prosthesis is a device designed to replace the function and appearance of a body part. Successful prosthetic use depends on patient and prosthesis factors, including pre-morbid activity level, contralateral limb status, trunk control, balance, motivation, and co-morbidities. Prosthetic factors include ease of use, aesthetics, durability, and comfort.

Gait abnormalities in transfemoral amputees can stem from prosthetic issues such as short prosthesis, weak abductors, or poor fit (lateral trunk bending), poor socket fit (abducted gait), excess knee friction or long prosthesis (circumducted gait), long prosthesis or poor suspension (vaulted gait), stiff heel or loose socket (foot rotation at heel-strike), and painful stump or loose knee (short stance phase).

Prosthetic knees offer various articulation types: Polycentric (four-bar linkage) allows varied Center of Rotation (COR) for better gait. Hydraulic/pneumatic knees provide fluid gait and varied resistance. Constant/Variable friction knees offer basic damping. Stance control knees lock in extension for stability, and manual locking knees provide maximum safety for very weak patients.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Energy Expenditure by Amputation Level for Ambulation
topics.text: The energy expenditure for ambulation increases significantly with more proximal amputations. Transfemoral amputations require about 65% more energy than a long transtibial amputation, which itself requires 10% more than an intact limb. Bilateral transtibial amputations also demand substantial energy.

Orthoses can limit motion (e.g., KO for knee hyperextension), correct deformity (e.g., Ponseti boots for clubfoot), or provide a combination of these. They influence joint moments and forces through control of bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of the ground reaction force (GRF).

Materials used in orthotics include traditional metals, leather, and rubber, as well as plastics like thermosetting and thermoforming plastics, and polyurethane foam. Foot orthoses include insoles (simple or total contact), functional orthotics (e.g., UCBL), shoe alterations (heel raises, rocker bottoms, metatarsal bars, heel wedges, arch supports), and custom-made shoes.

Ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) like Posterior Leaf Spring (for weak dorsiflexors), Ground Reaction AFO (GRAFO), and Dynamic AFO (DAFO) help control ankle and knee motion. Knee-ankle-foot orthoses (KAFOs) provide extension control. Patella tendon bearing orthoses reduce weight-bearing. Hydrostatic orthoses use soft tissue pressure to create stability.

Prosthetics replace the function and appearance of body parts. Successful use depends on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate myoplastic or myodesis techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load, while transfemoral prostheses require careful consideration of socket shape and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cup and femoral stem components, with various fixation methods and designs.

Complications of prostheses can be psychosocial or physical, including infection, neuroma, skin problems, phantom sensation/pain, and choke syndrome. Transfemoral prosthetic gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors. Increased energy consumption is noted with higher amputation levels.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities or weakness. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles, shoe alterations, and custom-made shoes. AFOs and KAFOs are used for lower limb support, while THPBs are used for fracture healing and neuropathic joints.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces through control of bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include thermosetting plastics, thermoforming plastics, and polyurethane foam. Different types of orthoses are used for various conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and UCBL inserts for foot correction.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance. Successful use depends on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Prosthetic knees offer various articulations: Polycentric (4-bar linkage) for variable COR, hydraulic/pneumatic for fluid gait, constant/variable friction for basic damping, stance control for stability, and manual locking for maximum safety. Each type aims to optimize function for different user needs.

topics.topic: Factors Negatively Influencing Amputation Stump Healing
topics.text: Poor stump healing can result from low albumin, low lymphocyte count, low transferrin, low ABPI, poor transcutaneous oxygen saturation, and anemia. These factors indicate compromised systemic health and peripheral circulation, impairing wound healing.

Ideal amputation levels balance limb length for prosthetic function with minimizing complications. For the forearm and humerus, the middle third is often preferred. Transtibial amputations aim for about 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity, and transfemoral amputations target the middle third of the femur.

A prosthesis comprises a socket (interface), suspension system (attachment), struts (length restoration), articulations (joint function), and a terminal device (hand or foot). The terminal device can be passive or active, controlled by cables or myoelectric signals.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Energy Expenditure by Amputation Level for Ambulation
topics.text: Ambulation energy expenditure increases significantly with amputation level. Transfemoral amputees require approximately 65% more energy than transtibial amputees. Bilateral amputations impose a substantial metabolic load, highlighting the importance of optimal stump and prosthetic fitting for functional independence.

Prosthetic knees offer various articulations: Polycentric (4-bar linkage) for dynamic COR, hydraulic/pneumatic for fluid gait, constant/variable friction for damping, stance control for stability, and manual locking for maximum safety. Each type aims to optimize function for different user needs and activity levels.

topics.text: Poor stump healing can result from low serum albumin, low lymphocyte count, low transferrin, low ABPI, poor transcutaneous oxygen saturation, and anemia. These factors indicate compromised systemic health and peripheral circulation, impairing wound healing and increasing the risk of complications.

Ideal amputation levels balance limb length for prosthetic function with minimizing complications. For the forearm and humerus, the middle third is often preferred. Transtibial amputations aim for approximately 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity, and transfemoral amputations target the middle third of the femur for optimal prosthetic fitting and function.

Each type aims to optimize function for different user needs and activity levels, improving mobility and independence.

These factors indicate compromised systemic health and peripheral circulation, impairing wound healing and increasing the risk of complications like infection or dehiscence.

Transtibial amputations aim for approximately 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity, and transfemoral amputations target the middle third of the femur for optimal prosthetic fitting and function, ensuring adequate muscle coverage and bone length.

The terminal device can be passive or active, controlled by cables, struts, or myoelectric signals, to restore function and improve quality of life for amputees.

Bone is composed of approximately 90% matrix and 10% cellular components, including osteoblasts (secrete osteoid), osteocytes (maintain bone), bone lining cells, osteoclasts (resorb bone), and osteoprogenitor cells. Osteoblasts are formed from mesenchymal stem cells and are responsible for bone formation.

Bone cement is composed of a liquid (monomer MMA, accelerator, inhibitor) and a powder (polymer PMMA, initiator, barium sulfate, antibiotics). Polymerization occurs upon mixing via an exothermic reaction, progressing through mixing, waiting (dough), working, hardening, and setting phases. Macroscopically, the stages are sandy, stringy, doughy, and final.

topics.topic: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
topics.text: Bone cement typically consists of a liquid monomer (MMA) and a powder polymer (PMMA), with accelerators and initiators. It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, with temperature influencing setting time. Proper technique is crucial to minimize porosity and maximize strength.

Bone formation occurs through three types: enchondral, intramembranous, and appositional. Enchondral ossification, the main type, involves replacing a cartilage model with bone, as seen in long bone growth and callus formation. Intramembranous ossification forms bone directly from undifferentiated cells in membranes, seen in flat bones. Appositional ossification contributes to bone width.

The body strives to maintain normal serum calcium, and imbalances in metabolic bone disorders reflect this effort. Calcium is primarily stored in bone as hydroxyapatite crystals. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate absorption, acting on the duodenum, bone, and parathyroid gland. PTH secretion is regulated by serum calcium and phosphate levels.

Bone remodeling is a cyclic process involving cytokines (IL6) recruiting osteoclasts, which secrete enzymes to resorb bone. Factors within the bone, like IGF-1, then recruit osteoblasts to lay down osteoid, which is mineralized by hydroxyapatite. IL6 from osteoblasts then recruits osteoclasts, restarting the cycle. Bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclast activity and are resistant to metabolism.

Bone remodeling is a continuous process throughout life where osteoclasts and osteoblasts work in tandem. Osteoclasts dissolve the mineral from the bone matrix, and osteoblasts produce new bone, called osteoid, to fill the resorption pit. Some osteoblasts remain embedded within the bone matrix as osteocytes.

The bone matrix consists of organic and inorganic components. The organic matrix is primarily type I collagen, providing tensile strength, along with proteoglycans and other matrix proteins. The inorganic matrix is mainly calcium hydroxyapatite, which provides compressive strength.

The cell cycle involves interphase (G1, S, G2) and mitosis (M). Cells in G0 are not dividing. DNA replication occurs in the S phase. Mitosis is cell division, resulting in two daughter nuclei. Understanding the cell cycle is relevant to non-sex cells.

The cell cycle consists of Interphase (G1, S, G2) and Mitosis (M). G1 is for growth, S for DNA synthesis, G2 for further growth and preparation for mitosis. M phase involves nuclear division (mitosis) and cell division (cytokinesis). G0 is a quiescent state where cells exit the cycle.

Bone cementing techniques have evolved significantly. Early methods involved finger packing. Second-generation techniques introduced cement guns and retrograde pressurization. Third-generation methods focus on reducing porosity (vacuum mixing), using pulse lavage, centralizers, and rough-stem finishes to improve cement mantle quality and implant fixation.

Bone cement undergoes distinct phases: Mixing (performed in vacuum to reduce porosity), Waiting (dough phase, viscosity increases), Working (manipulation time), and Hardening (complete hardening, influenced by temperature). Setting time is when cement reaches half its maximal heat.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
topics.text: Bone cement is typically a two-part mixture: a liquid monomer (MMA) with accelerator and inhibitor, and a powder polymer (PMMA) with initiator and dye. It undergoes phases of mixing, waiting (dough phase), working, and hardening, influenced by temperature. Proper mixing and manipulation are crucial for optimal strength and to avoid complications like porosity or premature setting.

Materials are defined by their mechanical properties. Brittle materials (e.g., PMMA) undergo elastic deformation, while ductile materials (e.g., metal) undergo plastic deformation. Viscoelastic materials (e.g., bone, ligaments) exhibit time-rate dependent behavior.

Metals used in orthopaedics include stainless steel, cobalt alloys, and titanium alloys. Fatigue failure occurs with cyclic loading below the ultimate tensile strength, while creep is progressive deformation under constant force. Corrosion is the chemical dissolving of metals.

Ceramics used in orthopaedics include bioinert materials like Alumina, Zircona, and Oxinium, and bioactive materials like Hydroxyapatite (HA) and Tricalcium Phosphate. Alumina is the most common ceramic, offering better quality. Zirconia is less used due to high fracture rates. Oxinium is oxidized zirconia. Hydroxyapatite is osteoconductive and promotes bone growth.

Orthopaedic implants are made from various metals, each with distinct compositions and properties. Stainless Steel 316L contains iron, chromium, nickel, molybdenum, and low carbon. Titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V) are lightweight and strong. Cobalt-Chrome alloys offer high strength and corrosion resistance. Understanding these compositions is vital for implant selection and managing potential adverse reactions.

Orthopaedic implants can undergo various types of corrosion: Uniform (affects entire surface), Galvanic (dissimilar metals create electrochemical gradient), Crevice (occurs in gaps), Pitting (localized corrosion), Fretting (combination of wear and corrosion), Intergranular (occurs at grain boundaries), Leaching (intra-granular corrosion), Inclusion (iatrogenic, due to retained fragments), and Stress corrosion (cyclic loading disrupts passive layer).

Implants for fracture fixation are primarily made of stainless steel or titanium alloys, chosen for their strength, stiffness, ductility, and biocompatibility. Titanium offers superior corrosion resistance and fatigue strength compared to stainless steel. Surface properties and coatings can influence osseointegration and reduce infection rates. Future developments include biodegradable polymers and additive manufacturing for personalized implants, along with the use of growth factors to enhance bone regeneration.

Locking plates utilize screws that lock into the plate, creating a fixed-angle construct and eliminating the need for plate-to-bone compression for stability. This is particularly advantageous in poor bone stock (osteoporotic bone) and metaphyseal fractures, where conventional screws may loosen. Locking plates also facilitate minimally invasive plate osteosynthesis (MIPO) by reducing the requirement for precise contouring. They can provide absolute or relative stability depending on the application and screw type used, offering a significant improvement over conventional plating techniques.

Metals used in orthopaedics have crystalline structures with defects like grain boundaries, dislocations, and cracks that affect mechanical properties. Alloys are combinations of metals with improved properties. Ductility can be reduced by adding large metal ions or small ions like carbon. Nickel and chromium increase corrosion resistance, while cobalt and molybdenum increase strength. Manufacturing processes include machining and casting, with grain size influenced by cooling rate.

Polyethylene, a polymer of ethylene, forms chains held by van der Waals forces. Its strength can be increased by increasing molecular weight, creating cross-links, reducing crystallinity, and optimizing manufacturing and sterilization methods. UHMWPE's strength and wear resistance are enhanced by increased chain length, number of chains, and amorphous proportion.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Mean Surface Roughness of Orthopaedic Materials
topics.text: The surface roughness of orthopaedic materials impacts articulation. Polished Exeter stems and ceramic heads have very low roughness (0.01-0.02), while polyethylene cups have higher roughness (2.0), and articular cartilage is around 3.0. This affects wear rates and friction.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Young's Modulus for Orthopaedic Materials
topics.text: Young's modulus quantifies material stiffness. Ceramics are the stiffest (250 GPa), followed by CoCr (225 GPa) and Titanium (100 GPa). Cortical bone is around 20 GPa, while PMMA is 2 GPa, and polyethylene is 1.5 GPa. Softer tissues like tendon (0.1 GPa) and cartilage (0.02 GPa) have much lower moduli.

Analgesics include opioids (mimic endogenous opioids, act on mu receptors via G proteins) and NSAIDs (inhibit prostaglandin production via COX enzymes). Paracetamol weakly inhibits COX and prostaglandins and has a central action. Local anesthetics block sodium channels in neurons, preventing action potential formation.

Prophylaxis for thromboembolic disease is recommended for all patients undergoing arthroplasty. Guidelines vary regarding the specific agents and duration of prophylaxis, considering factors such as bleeding risk, procedure type, and patient-specific risk factors.

Key orthopaedic medications include analgesics (Paracetamol, NSAIDs), opioids, steroids (immunosuppressive, anti-inflammatory), local anesthetics (Na+ channel blockers), anticoagulants (Warfarin, Heparin, LMWH, Fondaparinaux, Rivaroxaban), antiplatelets (Aspirin), bisphosphonates (inhibit osteoclasts), Strontium (affects bone turnover), DMARDs (Methotrexate, Etanercept, Infliximab), and Penicillamine.

Bias is the introduction of systematic prejudice into a study that skews its results. Types of bias include selection, observational, recall, and publication bias. Stratifying before randomization can also introduce bias.
A confounding error is a factor that skews study results but was not introduced, anticipated, or controllable by the observer.

Correlation tests measure the association between two variables, applicable to both parametric and non-parametric data. The value ranges from -1 to +1, indicating direct association. Pearson's correlation is used for parametric data, while Spearman's Rank Correlation is for non-parametric data.

Screening involves testing a large population for a disease of importance with low prevalence. WHO criteria for a screening test (1968) include the disease being important, having known incidence and natural history, available treatment, and the test being safe, inexpensive, cost-effective, sensitive, and specific.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity (TP/TP+FN), Specificity (TN/TN+FP), PPV, NPV, Accuracy, Reliability, Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, Incidence, P-value, Type 1 and Type 2 errors, and Power. Understanding these is essential for interpreting research findings and making evidence-based decisions in clinical practice.

Non-parametric tests are used for discrete data and include Chi Squared (analyzes differences between two categorical groups), Mann Whitney U, and Fishers Exact Test (used for small sample sizes, n<5, as a substitute for Chi Squared).

topics.topic: P values, Errors and Power analysis
topics.text: The null hypothesis assumes observed differences are due to chance. A p-value indicates the probability that a difference is not due to chance, with a p-value < 0.05 typically used to reject the null hypothesis. Type 1 (alpha) errors are false positives (incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis), while Type 2 (beta) errors are false negatives (incorrectly accepting the null hypothesis).

Parametric tests include the Unpaired Student T Test (compares means of two independent, normally distributed groups with similar variance) and ANOVA (used for multiple observations or categories, where groups are not completely independent). The Paired T Test compares two observations in the same subject.
Quality-Adjusted Life Years (QUALYS) are used to assess the cost-effectiveness of therapies, considering life expectancy, costs, and time.

Randomization reduces bias in studies by ensuring baseline characteristics of groups are similar, thereby avoiding confounding factors. Post-hoc power analysis can indicate the significance of positive findings.

RCTs progress through five phases: Pre-clinical (animal studies), Phase 1 (safety in healthy volunteers), Phase 2 (efficacy in a small patient group), Phase 3 (superiority against standard treatment), and Phase 4 (post-market surveillance).

Types of data include continuous (numeric, quantitative, e.g., age) and categorical (nominal, ordinal, qualitative, e.g., race). Parametric data typically follow a normal Gaussian distribution, where mean, median, and mode are similar. Non-parametric data are often skewed, with median or mode used to assess central tendency.

Deciding on an appropriate statistical test involves considering data distribution (normal/Gaussian vs. non-parametric), data type (discrete vs. continuous), number of variables, the research question (group differences vs. associations), and variance equality between groups.

Study designs include retrospective, prospective, cross-sectional, longitudinal, observational, and experimental. The hierarchy of study types places RCTs and meta-analyses of RCTs at the highest level of evidence. Cohort studies are prospective observational designs with a control group, while case-control studies are retrospective.

Survival analysis plots outcome data against time to assess survival. Methods include the actuarial method (survival calculated at set time points) and the Kaplan-Meier Product Limit method (recalculates survival after each failure). Life table analysis combines both methods. Reliable survival analysis requires clearly defined endpoints, failure criteria, and consistent treatment of loss to follow-up and death.

Survivorship analysis determines the number of joints followed and the number of failures and censored patients on a yearly basis. Censored patients include those withdrawn or lost to follow-up. Survival calculations are based on surviving implants divided by patients at risk, with adjustments for censored patients.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity (TP/TP+FN), Specificity (TN/TN+FP), PPV (TP/TP+FP), NPV (TN/TN+FN), Accuracy, Reliability (inter/intra-observer), Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, Incidence, P-value, Type 1 & 2 errors, and Power. These terms are crucial for interpreting research and clinical data.

Statistical tests used in research include the Student T-test (parametric, 2 variables), ANOVA (parametric, multiple variables), Chi-Squared test (non-parametric, discrete variables), Mann-Whitney U (non-parametric, continuous data), and Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric, multiple variables). Yates' correction and Fisher's exact test are used for small sample sizes with Chi-Squared.

Validity refers to how accurately a test measures what it is supposed to. Internal validity relates to the confidence in the cause-and-effect relationship, while external validity concerns the applicability of results to the general population. Reliability refers to the reproducibility of a test, assessed by intra-observer and inter-observer agreement. ROC curves illustrate the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV, Accuracy, Reliability, Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, and Incidence. Understanding these is essential for interpreting research findings, evaluating diagnostic tests, and making evidence-based clinical decisions, ensuring a scientific approach to patient care.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV, Accuracy, Reliability, Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, and Incidence. Understanding these is essential for interpreting research findings, evaluating diagnostic tests, and making evidence-based clinical decisions in orthopaedics.

Calcitonin reduces serum calcium by inhibiting osteoclast activity. Corticosteroids can decrease serum calcium by increasing renal excretion and reducing gut absorption, potentially leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Estrogen is bone-protective, inhibiting osteoclast absorption and bone production.

Growth hormone increases gut calcium absorption and maintains bone stock. Thyroid hormones influence bone turnover, with hyperthyroidism leading to decreased bone density. Growth factors like BMPs and TGF-beta are osteoinductive, stimulating bone formation. Osteoporosis is characterized by reduced bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration, increasing fracture risk, and can be primary (Type 1: postmenopausal, Type 2: age-related) or secondary (steroids, immobilization).

The mechanical properties of cement include weak tensile strength, moderate shear strength, and strong compressive strength. It is brittle and highly notch-sensitive, acting as a grout rather than an adhesive. Factors affecting cement properties include atmospheric conditions (temperature/humidity), mixing technique (vacuum/centrifuge reduce porosity), and implantation technique (pressurization, retention of cancellous bone, avoiding voids).

Complications of bone cement use include heat generation (causing bone necrosis if the mantle is too thick), systemic effects (hypotension thought to be due to micro-embolization), and cement fracture due to crack propagation. Commonly used cements include Palacos R (zirconium dioxide, gentamicin impregnated) and Simplex P (barium sulfate, tobramycin impregnated).

Forging is a common method of shaping metal implants, aligning grain boundaries and improving properties. Cold working increases strength and brittleness through plastic deformation, while hot working yields a more ductile material. Heat treatments like annealing, quenching, and tempering alter metal properties. Surface finishes like polished, matte, grit blasted, sintered beads, plasma spray, and porous metal improve performance.

Commonly used materials include 316L Stainless Steel (strong, ductile, corrosion-resistant) and Titanium 64 (less stiff than CoCr/Steel but fatigue resistant). Cobalt Chrome (CoCr) is widely used in TKA and THR due to its wear properties and biocompatibility. Tantalum, with its high porosity, allows rapid bone ingrowth and is desirable for revision surgery.

Cross-linking polyethylene, often via gamma irradiation, improves wear rates and tensile strength by forming cross-links between chains. However, oxidation degrades polyethylene, especially in the presence of oxygen and free radicals. Better sterilization methods include gas plasma or ethylene oxide (minimizing oxidation) or gamma irradiation in inert gas (promoting cross-links).

Highly cross-linked UHMWPE, produced by prolonged irradiation, offers even better wear resistance. However, this degree of cross-linking can reduce fatigue resistance and fracture toughness. Polyethylene in TKR can fail due to fatigue fracture, while poorly positioned THR cups are susceptible to edge loading and fatigue wear. Polyethylene manufacturing methods include RAM bar extrusion, compression molding, and direct compression molding (gold standard).

Ceramic manufacturing involves pressing powder into a cast, followed by sintering (hot isostatic pressing) to increase density, toughness, and strength. Other processes include platelet-like crystals and transformational toughening (using zircona). Good properties of ceramics include inertness, stiffness, hardness, low surface roughness, and scratch profile. Brittleness and weakness in tension are disadvantages.

Oxidized Zirconium (Oxinium) is a metallic alloy with a ceramic surface, offering hardness, smoothness, scratch resistance, inertness, and wettability, with reduced poly wear. Ceramic fracture can generate third bodies, leading to accelerated wear and osteolysis, necessitating synovectomy to clear debris. Revision may be required for Morse taper damage.

Measures of spread/variability include interquartile range (describes deviation from the mean in 25% quartiles) and standard deviation (describes deviation of individual values from the mean, used in normal distributions). Variance is the standard deviation squared. Confidence intervals indicate the accuracy of a measurement.

Incidence refers to the number of new diagnoses in a defined population over time, often expressed as an incidence rate. Prevalence is the number of people with a condition at a given time (a snapshot). Sensitivity measures the test's ability to correctly identify those with the disease (true positives), minimizing false negatives (TP/(TP+FN)). Specificity measures the test's ability to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives), minimizing false positives (TN/(TN+FP)).

Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the likelihood that a positive test result is truly positive (TP/(TP+FP)). Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the likelihood that a negative test result is truly negative (TN/(TN+FN)). Accuracy is the proportion of all true results (TP+TN)/(TP+FP+TN+FN). Odds Ratio, used in case-control studies, compares the likelihood of a positive finding in the study group versus the control group.

Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, modifying gene transcription and suppressing macrophage function. Side effects are numerous, encapsulated by the mnemonic 'I WAS HOPPING MAD'. Anti-coagulants like warfarin (inhibits Vitamin K-dependent factors) and heparin (complexes with antithrombin III) are used to prevent clotting.

LMWH also complexes with antithrombin III but selectively inhibits factor 10a. Fondaparinaux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits factor 10a. Rivaroxaban acts directly on factor 10a, while Dabigatran inhibits thrombin. Aspirin inhibits COX-1 and prostaglandin production, preventing platelet aggregation.

Strontium has anabolic (increases bone formation) and catabolic (decreases bone resorption) effects. Anti-rheumatic drugs include non-disease modifying (steroids, cyclophosphamide) and disease-modifying agents (methotrexate, sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine), as well as biologic response modifiers (entanercept, infliximab, rituximab).

Data types are continuous (numeric, quantitative) and categorical (nominal, ordinal, qualitative). Parametric data follow a normal distribution, while non-parametric data are skewed. Statistical tests like the T test and ANOVA are used for parametric data, while Chi Squared, Mann Whitney U, and Fishers Exact Test are used for non-parametric data. Correlation tests measure associations between variables.

Screening tests should be important, have known incidence and natural history, available treatment, and be safe, inexpensive, sensitive, and specific. Incidence measures new cases over time, while prevalence measures existing cases at a given time. Sensitivity identifies true positives, and specificity identifies true negatives. Predictive values indicate the likelihood of a positive or negative result being correct.

Survival analysis plots outcomes against time, using methods like actuarial and Kaplan-Meier. It requires clearly defined endpoints and consistent treatment of loss to follow-up. Survivorship analysis tracks the number of implants followed, failures, and censored patients, recalculating survival based on patients at risk.

Analgesics include opioids (acting on CNS receptors) and NSAIDs (inhibiting prostaglandin production). Paracetamol has central action. Local anesthetics block sodium channels. Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory effects but numerous side effects. Anti-coagulants like warfarin and heparin prevent clotting by inhibiting specific factors or complexes.

Bone remodeling is a continuous process involving osteoclasts (resorption) and osteoblasts (formation), regulated by hormones like PTH, Vitamin D, and calcitonin. Osteoporosis is characterized by reduced bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration, with primary (Type 1 and 2) and secondary causes. Management includes lifestyle modifications, medical treatments (bisphosphonates, HRT, calcitonin), and increasing bone density through exercise and recombinant PTH.

Data can be continuous (numeric) or categorical (non-numeric). Parametric data follow a normal distribution, allowing use of T tests and ANOVA. Non-parametric tests (Chi Squared, Mann Whitney U, Fishers Exact) are used for skewed or categorical data. Correlation tests measure associations, with Pearson's for parametric and Spearman's for non-parametric data.

Screening tests must be important, common, have known incidence and natural history, available treatment, and be safe, sensitive, and specific. Incidence measures new cases, prevalence measures existing cases. Sensitivity identifies true positives, specificity true negatives. Predictive values assess the likelihood of a test result being correct. ROC curves illustrate sensitivity-trait relationships.

Survival analysis tracks outcomes over time using actuarial or Kaplan-Meier methods. Life table analysis combines both. Reliable survival analysis requires defined endpoints, clear failure criteria, and consistent handling of censored data. Survivorship analysis tracks implant performance yearly.

Analgesics include opioids (acting on CNS receptors) and NSAIDs (inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis via COX). Paracetamol has central action. Local anesthetics block sodium channels. Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory effects but numerous side effects. Anti-coagulants like warfarin and heparin prevent clotting by interfering with specific factors.

Bone remodeling is a continuous process involving osteoclasts and osteoblasts, regulated by hormones. Osteoporosis results from reduced bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration. Management includes lifestyle modifications, bisphosphonates, HRT, and exercise. Different fixation methods and materials (metals, polyethylene, ceramics) are used in arthroplasty, each with specific properties and failure modes.

Bone metabolism is regulated by calcium and phosphate homeostasis, influenced by Vitamin D, PTH, and calcitonin. Osteoblasts produce osteoid and RANKL, while osteoclasts resorb bone, regulated by RANKL and OPG. Bone matrix consists of inorganic (hydroxyapatite) and organic (collagen) components.

topics.topic: Useful Tables: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
topics.text: Bone cement typically consists of a liquid monomer (MMA) and a powder polymer (PMMA), with accelerators, initiators, and inhibitors. It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, influenced by temperature and handling techniques. Proper mixing is crucial to minimize porosity.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV, Accuracy, Reliability, Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, Incidence, P-value, Type 1 and Type 2 errors, and Power. Understanding these is essential for interpreting research findings and making evidence-based decisions.

Common statistical tests include the Student T-test and ANOVA for parametric data, and Chi-Squared, Mann-Whitney U, and Kruskal-Wallis for non-parametric data. These tests help determine the significance of observed differences between groups.

Orthopaedic medications include analgesics (Paracetamol, NSAIDs, Opioids), anti-inflammatories (Steroids), anticoagulants (Warfarin, Heparin, LMWH), antiplatelets (Aspirin), bone metabolism modulators (Bisphosphonates, Strontium), DMARDs (Methotrexate, Etanercept, Infliximab), and local anesthetics. Understanding their mechanisms and indications is vital.

Orthopaedic implants utilize metals like Stainless Steel 316L, Titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V), and Cobalt-Chrome alloys. Each metal has a specific composition and properties influencing its strength, corrosion resistance, and biocompatibility, guiding implant selection for different applications.

The cell cycle comprises Interphase (G1, S, G2) and Mitosis (M). G1 is for growth, S for DNA synthesis, G2 for further growth and preparation for division. M phase involves nuclear and cellular division. G0 represents cells that have exited the cycle, like neurons.

Orthopaedic implants are susceptible to various corrosion types: Uniform (overall surface attack), Galvanic (dissimilar metals), Crevice (in gaps), Pitting (localized), Fretting (wear + corrosion), Intergranular (at grain boundaries), Leaching (intra-granular), Inclusion (retained fragments), and Stress corrosion (cyclic loading). Understanding these is vital for implant longevity.

Understanding their mechanisms and indications is vital for patient management.

Each metal has distinct compositional and mechanical properties influencing implant strength, corrosion resistance, and biocompatibility, guiding selection for optimal patient outcomes.

It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, influenced by temperature and handling. Proper mixing is vital to minimize porosity and maximize cement strength for implant fixation.

Understanding these is vital for implant longevity and patient safety.

Understanding their mechanisms and indications is vital for patient management and optimizing surgical outcomes.

Orthopaedic implants utilize metals like Stainless Steel 316L, Titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V), and Cobalt-Chrome alloys. Each metal has distinct compositional and mechanical properties influencing implant strength, corrosion resistance, and biocompatibility, guiding selection for optimal patient outcomes and minimizing adverse reactions like ion release.

M phase includes mitosis (nuclear division) and cytokinesis (cell division). G0 represents cells exiting the cycle, like neurons, indicating their non-dividing state.

topics.topic: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
topics.text: Bone cement typically consists of a liquid monomer (MMA) and a powder polymer (PMMA), with accelerators and inhibitors. It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, influenced by temperature and handling. Proper mixing is vital to minimize porosity and maximize cement strength for implant fixation, reducing the risk of loosening and failure.

Orthopaedic implants are susceptible to corrosion: Uniform (overall surface attack), Galvanic (dissimilar metals), Crevice (in gaps), Pitting (localized), Fretting (wear + corrosion), Intergranular (at grain boundaries), Leaching (intra-granular), Inclusion (retained fragments), and Stress corrosion (cyclic loading). Understanding these is vital for implant longevity and patient safety, minimizing adverse tissue reactions and implant failure.

External fixation devices depend on the desired effect (temporary or definitive). Working length is critical, similar to nails and plates. Placing bars closer to the skin reduces working length and increases construct stiffness. Stiffness can be increased by larger pin/bar size, shorter working length, more pins, multiple planes, anatomical reduction, and underdrilling holes.

External fixators are versatile devices that can be used for indirect reduction and stabilization of fractures. Schanz screws are inserted into bone fragments, and these are connected by rods or tubes. Modular clamps allow for unrestricted positioning of the screws and frame components, enabling reduction in multiple planes. The system can be adapted for various anatomical areas, including joints, and offers advantages in preserving bone and soft-tissue vascularity. Special applications include arthrodesis, managing infected fractures, corrective osteotomies, bone transport, and joint stabilization.

Various instruments aid fracture reduction: reduction forceps (Weber, toothed, self-centering), bone spreaders for distraction, pelvic reduction forceps (Queen tong, Matta, Farabeuf, Jungbluth) for complex pelvic and acetabular fractures, and colinear reduction forceps for linear force application. The choice depends on the fracture pattern, bone size, and desired reduction technique.

Lag screws achieve interfragmentary compression by utilizing a glide hole in the near cortex and a pilot hole in the far cortex. As the screw tightens, it pulls the near fragment against the far fragment, compressing the fracture site. This compression is essential for direct bone healing and stability, especially in simple fracture patterns. Multiple lag screws, placed at optimal angles, enhance stability against rotational forces.

Lag screws achieve interfragmentary compression by using a glide hole in the near cortex and a pilot hole in the far cortex. As the screw advances, its head compresses against the near cortex, pulling the fragments together. Fully threaded screws require precise gliding holes, while partially threaded cancellous screws utilize the smooth shaft as the glide hole. Proper placement, ideally perpendicular to the fracture plane or inclined halfway between the perpendiculars, maximizes compression and stability.

MIPO aims to reduce surgical trauma by using indirect reduction and small incisions, preserving soft tissue and bone vascularity. It relies on preoperative planning, intraoperative imaging, and specialized instruments to achieve stable fixation. This technique is particularly beneficial for metaphyseal fractures, those with compromised soft tissues, or when anatomical reduction is challenging, leading to biological healing with callus formation.

MIPO utilizes implants like LC-DCPs, which offer limited bone contact and are available in various sizes and configurations. Locking head screws (LHS) provide angular stability, crucial in osteoporotic bone or complex metaphyseal fractures. The choice between anatomical plates and conventional straight plates depends on the fracture pattern and the need for contouring. Proper technique, including avoiding excessive traction on soft tissues and careful screw placement, is paramount to prevent complications.

MIPO requires meticulous preoperative planning, including assessing the patient's condition, understanding fracture patterns, knowing 'danger zones' for approaches, deciding between absolute or relative stability, and planning the sequence of reduction, fixation, and soft-tissue management. Proper patient positioning and utilizing the contralateral limb as a template are crucial for achieving correct length, alignment, and rotation.

Closed reduction using indirect techniques is central to MIPO. This involves leveraging traction, ligamentotaxis, and specialized instruments like distractors, clamps, and joysticks to reduce fragments without direct visualization. Maintaining reduction with temporary fixation (e.g., K-wires, plates) is essential for intraoperative C-arm control and accurate definitive fixation. Cerclage wires can also be used percutaneously for reduction, especially in spiral fractures.

MIPO is applicable to various long bone segments, including the humerus, femur, and tibia. Proximal humerus fractures are often approached via a deltopectoral or lateral split approach. Humeral shaft fractures can be approached anteriorly or laterally. Femoral fractures may use MIPO when nailing is contraindicated. Proximal tibial fractures benefit from MIPO, especially those with soft-tissue compromise, while diaphyseal tibial fractures are generally best treated with IM nailing. Distal tibia fractures, particularly those involving the joint, require anatomical reduction and MIPO offers a viable approach.

Preoperative planning is essential for successful fracture management. It involves assessing the patient, injury 'personality' (soft tissues, fracture pattern), and available resources. Planning includes reconstructing the fracture using X-rays and templates, deciding on the fixation method (IM nail, plate, external fixator), determining the surgical approach, and outlining a detailed step-by-step surgical tactic. This process minimizes intraoperative complications, optimizes outcomes, and facilitates informed consent.

Screws function by converting rotational force into linear motion via their threads. The axial force generated depends on thread pitch and friction. Excessive torque during insertion can cause thermal necrosis of bone, screw loosening, or stripping of the drive recess. Locking head screws (LHS) engage threads in the plate, providing angular stability without significant preload, unlike conventional screws which rely on friction and compression for fixation.

topics.topic: Screws in Fracture Fixation: Design and Function
topics.text: Screws convert rotation into linear motion, fixing bone fragments or plates. Key design features include a central core for strength, threads for bone engagement, a tip for insertion, a head for attachment, and a recess for a screwdriver. Screws are categorized by their design (cannulated, locking head), dimensions, characteristics (self-tapping), and application (cortex, cancellous). They function as lag screws for compression, plate screws, position screws, locking head screws for angular stability, or anchor screws.

Lag screws are crucial for absolute stability in articular fractures. Minimally invasive plate osteosynthesis (MIPO) utilizes screws percutaneously. Proper technique, including correct screw length selection (often 2mm longer than measured for self-tapping screws), careful insertion to avoid toggling, and appropriate torque, is vital. Monocortical screws are used when bicortical purchase is impossible, but offer less stability.

topics.topic: Screws: Clinical Applications and Insertion Techniques
topics.text: Lag screws are essential for achieving absolute stability in articular fractures and simple diaphyseal fractures. Proper insertion technique, including correct glide hole and pilot hole preparation, countersinking, and appropriate torque, is vital. For MIPO, specialized instruments and techniques are used to place screws percutaneously, ensuring accurate reduction and stable fixation while minimizing soft-tissue damage.

Screws serve multiple functions in fracture fixation: plate screws fix plates to bone, lag screws compress fragments, position screws hold fragments without compression, locking head screws provide angular stability with plates, interlocking screws stabilize IM nails, anchor screws fix wires/sutures, push-pull screws aid reduction, and reduction screws help approximate fragments to plates during MIPO.

Screw threads are designed for cortex (fine thread) or cancellous bone (coarse thread). Cortex screws have a pitch of 1.75 mm, while cancellous screws have a deeper thread and larger pitch. LHS have shallow threads and are designed to lock into the plate. Screw tips can be smooth (requiring tapping), self-tapping (cutting their own threads), or self-drilling/tapping. Proper thread engagement and avoiding excessive heat are crucial for screw purchase and stability.

Tension band fixation can be static or dynamic. Static examples include medial malleolar fractures where compression is constant. Dynamic examples, like patellar or olecranon fractures, convert tension into compression during joint movement. Techniques include wire loops, cables, sutures, and plates, all aiming to neutralize distraction and promote compression for optimal bone healing.

topics.topic: Tension Band Fixation: Prerequisites and Complications
topics.text: Successful tension band fixation requires the bone to withstand compression, an intact opposite cortex to act as a buttress, and a strong fixation construct. Common complications include K-wire loosening or breakage, prominent hardware, implant failure, and fracture displacement if reduction or fixation is inadequate. Proper technique, particularly in achieving correct wire/screw placement and tension, is crucial.

topics.topic: Tension Band Principle in Fracture Fixation
topics.text: The tension band principle converts tensile forces into compressive forces at the fracture site, promoting healing. This is achieved by applying fixation eccentrically on the convex side of a curved bone or fragment. In fractures of the patella, olecranon, or greater tuberosity, wire loops or cables neutralize distraction forces. For diaphyseal fractures, plates applied to the tension side can achieve compression, provided the opposite cortex acts as a buttress.

Orthopaedic screw sets are categorized into small and large fragment sets, each containing cortical, cancellous, and locking screws of various diameters and corresponding drill bit and tap sizes. These are essential for fracture fixation and provide different strengths and holding capabilities.

Theatre layout and design are crucial for infection control, with distinct zones (outer, clean, aseptic, disposal) linked by corridors to prevent cross-contamination. Careful control of temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation is maintained. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne, originating from people in the theatre, with acceptable CFU/m values for different theatre cleanliness levels.

Diathermy uses high-frequency electrical current for tissue heating (cutting or coagulation). Monopolar diathermy concentrates heat at the active electrode, while bipolar diathermy uses current between the instrument tips, making it safer for patients with pacemakers. Risks include burns from pooling of flammable skin prep, arcing with implants, and electrosurgical unit malfunctions.

Diathermy uses high-frequency electrical current for tissue heating (cutting or coagulation). Monopolar diathermy concentrates heat at the active electrode, while bipolar diathermy is safer for patients with pacemakers. Risks include burns from flammable prep, arcing with implants, and electrosurgical unit malfunctions. Proper technique and safety precautions are essential to prevent intraoperative complications.

Monopolar diathermy concentrates heat at the active electrode, while bipolar diathermy is safer for patients with pacemakers. Risks include burns from flammable prep, arcing with implants, and electrosurgical unit malfunctions. Proper technique and safety precautions are essential to prevent intraoperative complications and ensure patient safety.

Proper cuff width and pressure are crucial. Limb exanguination enhances effectiveness but is contraindicated in infection or metastatic disease. Tourniquet duration should be limited (<2 hours) to minimize complications like neuropraxia and muscle ischemia, with careful monitoring post-deflation.

Following nerve injury, proximal axons undergo metabolic changes to promote regeneration, while distal segments experience Wallerian degeneration. Schwann cells proliferate to guide regenerating axons. Motor end plates require re-innervation within months for functional recovery; beyond this timeframe, irreversible muscle atrophy can occur, impacting functional outcomes and necessitating careful monitoring and rehabilitation.

Sunderland's grading (1-5) refines this based on connective tissue damage, crucial for predicting recovery and guiding surgical intervention decisions for nerve repair or grafting, aiming to restore nerve function and sensation.

Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) can be caused by vascular compression of the subclavian artery or plexus, or by neurologic compression. Neurologic TOS is less common and affects T1 and C7 nerve roots. Symptoms may include pain radiating down the arm, intrinsic muscle weakness, and clawing of the fingers. Provocative tests like Adson's, Wright's, and Roo's tests can help diagnose TOS.

Median nerve compression can occur in the forearm, leading to pronator syndrome or anterior interosseous syndrome. Pronator syndrome involves compression of the median nerve, not necessarily between the pronator teres heads. Anterior interosseous syndrome causes weakness but typically not pain. EMG is useful for diagnosing these conditions.

Nerve conduction studies (NCS) and EMG are used to assess nerve function. Latency, amplitude, and velocity provide information about nerve conduction quality and quantity. Factors affecting nerve conduction include age, temperature, limb, and nerve location. Radial nerve lesions can occur in the upper arm (fracture, palsy), elbow (PIN palsy, radial tunnel syndrome), or forearm. Median nerve lesions include pronator syndrome and anterior interosseous syndrome.

Informed consent is a cornerstone of medical practice, requiring patient understanding, capacity, and voluntary agreement. The process should be a partnership between doctor and patient, involving clear explanation of the procedure, risks (common and serious), benefits, and alternatives, with ample opportunity for questions. Consent should be documented in writing.

Preoperative planning is a crucial professional discipline in orthopaedic trauma. It involves analyzing the patient's 'personality' (comorbidities, health status), the soft-tissue injury, and the fracture pattern. Detailed planning, including meticulous review of X-rays and CT scans, selecting appropriate implants and approaches, and outlining a step-by-step surgical tactic, minimizes intraoperative complications, optimizes outcomes, and facilitates informed consent.

Various instruments aid fracture reduction: reduction forceps (pointed, toothed, self-centering, colinear), bone spreaders for distraction, pelvic reduction forceps (King tong, Matta, Farabeuf, Jungbluth) for complex pelvic/acetabular fractures, Hohmann retractors for leverage, and joystick techniques with K-wires or Schanz screws for manipulating fragments. Proper use of these instruments is essential for achieving accurate reduction with minimal soft-tissue damage.

Screw threads vary: cortex screws have finer threads for dense bone, while cancellous screws have coarser threads for softer bone. LHS have shallow threads for plate engagement. Screw tips can be smooth (requiring tapping), self-tapping (cutting threads), or self-drilling/tapping. Proper selection and insertion of screws, considering bone quality and avoiding thermal damage, are critical for successful fixation.

MIPO requires meticulous planning, including patient positioning, assessing fracture patterns and soft tissue envelope, and understanding 'danger zones' for approaches. Surgeons must decide between absolute or relative stability, select appropriate implants (e.g., LC-DCPs, anatomical plates), and develop a detailed surgical tactic, including reduction strategies and screw insertion order, to minimize intraoperative complications and optimize outcomes.

Closed reduction using indirect techniques is key to MIPO. This involves traction, ligamentotaxis, and specialized instruments like distractors, clamps, and joysticks to manipulate fragments without direct visualization. Maintaining reduction with temporary fixation (e.g., K-wires, plates) is crucial for intraoperative C-arm control and definitive fixation. Cerclage wires can also be used percutaneously for reduction, particularly in spiral fractures.

MIPO utilizes implants like LC-DCPs and anatomical LCPs, offering limited bone contact and modular fixation. Locking head screws (LHS) provide angular stability, beneficial in osteoporotic bone or complex metaphyseal fractures. The choice between anatomical and straight plates, and the technique of contouring, depend on the fracture pattern and site. Proper technique is crucial to avoid complications like soft-tissue breakdown or malunion.

MIPO is applicable to various long bones, including the humerus, femur, and tibia. Proximal humerus fractures often use a deltopectoral or lateral split approach. Humeral shaft fractures can be approached anteriorly or laterally. Femoral fractures may benefit from MIPO when nailing is contraindicated. Tibial fractures, especially proximal ones with soft-tissue compromise, are well-suited for MIPO. Distal tibia fractures, particularly intra-articular ones, require anatomical reduction, and MIPO offers a viable approach.
