Lag screws are crucial for absolute stability in articular fractures and simple diaphyseal fractures. Proper insertion technique, including correct screw length selection (often 2mm longer than measured for self-tapping screws), careful drilling to avoid thermal necrosis, and appropriate torque, is vital. Monocortical screws offer less stability and are typically used when bicortical purchase is impossible or to avoid certain structures.

topics.topic: Tension Band Principle in Fracture Fixation
topics.text: The tension band principle converts tensile forces into compressive forces at the fracture site, promoting healing. This is achieved by applying fixation eccentrically on the convex side of a curved bone or fragment. In fractures of the patella, olecranon, or greater tuberosity, wire loops or cables neutralize distraction forces. Plates can also function as tension bands, especially in diaphyseal malunions or nonunions, by applying compression to the opposite cortex.

Tension band fixation can be static or dynamic. Static examples include medial malleolar fractures where compression is constant. Dynamic examples, like patellar or olecranon fractures, convert tension into compression during joint movement. Techniques include wire loops, cables, sutures, and plates, all aiming to neutralize distraction and promote compression for optimal bone healing. Biodegradable materials are also being used.

topics.topic: Tension Band Fixation: Prerequisites and Complications
topics.text: Successful tension band fixation requires the bone to withstand compression, an intact opposite cortex to act as a buttress, and a strong fixation construct. Common complications include K-wire loosening or breakage, prominent hardware, implant failure, and fracture displacement if reduction or fixation is inadequate. Proper technique, especially in achieving correct wire/screw placement and tension, is crucial for successful outcomes.

Wartenberg's Syndrome involves compression of the superficial radial nerve in the forearm, causing pain and numbness without weakness.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Congenital Radial Head Dislocation
topics.text: Congenital dislocation of the radial head, most commonly anterior, presents with a fullness over the radial aspect, restricted supination and extension, and may be associated with cubitus valgus or varus. Examine the contralateral elbow and screen for associated conditions like Nail Patella syndrome or achondroplasia. Management is usually non-operative unless there is significant pain or reduced ROM.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Cubitus Valgus/Varus and Nerve Status
topics.text: Assessing cubitus valgus or varus involves evaluating ROM and palpating the medial epicondyle and ulna nerve for pain or subluxation. Crucially, examine the ulnar nerve's status in the hand, assessing sensation in the little finger and ulnar side of the dorsum, and motor function of intrinsic muscles and the flexor digitorum profundus to the ring finger. Tests like Tinel's at the cubital tunnel and the Wartenberg sign help localize nerve issues.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: General Assessment
topics.text: General elbow examination involves inspecting for scars, asymmetry, carrying angle, swelling, and obvious loss of motion. Assess active and passive ROM in extension, flexion, supination, and pronation, comparing to the contralateral side. Palpate systematically for pain over the lateral epicondyle, RC joint, olecranon, medial epicondyle, and ulna nerve, assessing for subluxation or tenderness.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Radio-Ulnar Synostosis
topics.text: Radio-ulnar synostosis involves the failure of differentiation of the radius and ulna, typically resulting in a fixed pronation deformity. Examination may reveal scars from trauma, limb shortening, and restricted pronation/supination. Traumatic synostosis is associated with high-energy injuries, head injuries, and restricted post-operative ROM. Management is often non-operative due to poor surgical outcomes.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Rheumatoid Arthritis
topics.text: Examining an elbow with rheumatoid arthritis involves noting the typical rheumatoid features in the hand, wrist, and shoulder, along with any scars on the elbow. Assess elbow ROM, noting pain, crepitus, and warmth. Examine the ulnar nerve for neurological deficits and screen for spinal involvement. Functional assessment includes grip strength and the ability to perform daily activities.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Stiff Elbow
topics.text: Evaluating a stiff elbow involves assessing both active and passive range of motion to identify any pain within the arc of movement and quantify the degree of stiffness. Functional assessment includes the ability to bring the hand to the mouth and perineum. The presence of crepitus or pain with varus/valgus stress is also noted.

topics.topic: Examination of the Elbow: Tennis or Golfer's Elbow
topics.text: For suspected tennis or golfer's elbow, provocative tests include resisted wrist extension and third finger extension for tennis elbow, and resisted finger flexion for golfer's elbow. Assessment also involves palpating the epicondyles for tenderness and evaluating elbow ROM for any pain or restriction.

Assessing shoulder instability involves looking for asymmetry, wasting, and signs of hyperlaxity (Beighton's score). Palpate the axillary nerve for function. Special tests include the sulcus sign, anterior and posterior load shift tests (sitting), and the anterior apprehension test (lying). Testing the long head of biceps (LHB) if other tests are equivocal is also part of the assessment.

topics.topic: Examination of the Shoulder: Rotator Cuff, Impingement, and ACJ Arthritis
topics.text: Shoulder examination begins with inspection for asymmetry, scars, and muscle wasting in the deltoid, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus fossae. Palpate the clavicle, ACJ, acromion, LHB, and scapula. Assess active and passive ROM, noting pain, impingement arcs, and scapular winging. Special tests like Hawkins impingement, Jobes, and cross-arm adduction help identify rotator cuff pathology and ACJ involvement. Evaluating LHB and subscapularis strength is also important.

topics.topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: History and Inspection
topics.text: Brachial plexus examination begins with a history of birth trauma, prematurity, or associated conditions. Inspection includes observing limb posture, muscle wasting, fasciculations, scars (indicating previous exploration or nerve transfers), bony malunion, Horner's syndrome, and any walking aids or orthoses. Assessing the C-spine is also important due to potential associated injuries.

topics.topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: Palpation and Movement
topics.text: Palpation involves assessing bony landmarks for old fractures and evaluating sensation along dermatomes and peripheral nerve distributions. Motor testing is performed systematically by nerve root (C5-T1), trunk, cord, and branch levels to assess specific muscle groups like the rhomboids, serratus anterior, deltoid, biceps, and intrinsic hand muscles.

Assessing for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome involves examining the neck and shoulders for associated issues, screening hands and wrists for scars and thenar wasting, and evaluating sensation in the radial three digits and thenar eminence. Motor assessment includes APB and FDS power. Special tests like Tinel's sign over the carpal tunnel and Durkin's compression test help confirm the diagnosis.

Assessing nerve lesions involves evaluating sensation and motor function for radial, ulnar, median, musculocutaneous, and axillary nerves. Specific myotomes and dermatomes are tested to localize the lesion. Special tests like Tinel's, Phalen's, and Froment's sign help differentiate nerve entrapment or injury sites.

In rheumatoid arthritis, the hand examination reveals extensor surface changes like ulnar deviation, MCPJ subluxation, Z-thumb deformity, Boutonniere/Swan neck deformities, rheumatoid nodules, and joint inflammation. Flexor surface findings include trigger fingers and other deformities. Functional assessment includes grip, pinch, and chuck pinch strength.

topics.topic: Hand Examination: Screen and Refined Assessment
topics.text: The initial hand screen involves exposing the arms above the elbows, making a fist, opening the hands, and raising the arms to assess elbows and posterior arms. A refined examination involves inspecting and palpating for swelling, tenderness, mobility, and skin changes, and assessing distal neurological and vascular status. Special tests like Allen's test and specific tests for Dupuytren's contracture (Hueson's table test) are then performed.

topics.topic: Examination of Patellofemoral Joint Rotational Abnormalities
topics.text: Examination of the patellofemoral joint for rotational abnormalities includes assessing coronal alignment, Q angle, foot pronation, scars, quad bulk, swelling, and Beighton's score. Gait analysis should note foot progression angle and patella orientation. Sitting, assess extensor mechanism competence, crepitus, tracking, and patella alta. Lying down, evaluate for effusion, facet pain, MPFL tenderness, patella excursion, tilt, and ROM. Examination of the thigh-foot angle and femoral version (prone) is also crucial.

topics.text: Nuclear medicine studies, such as bone scans, gallium scans, and indium scans, are valuable for detecting inflammation, infection, and neoplasia by assessing blood flow and metabolic activity. topics.topic: Imaging and Special Studies: Radiation safety
topics.text: Radiation safety should be considered in all fluoroscopic cases, with factors like imaging larger body parts, positioning the extremity closer to the x-source, and using large C-arms increasing exposure. Minimizing exposure time, using collimation, and employing protective shielding can reduce radiation dose.

Different medical imaging procedures involve varying radiation doses. Angiography can deliver up to 57 mSv over 15-20 years. A CT neck is about 0.6 mSv, CT Abdomen/Pelvis 10 mSv, and CXR 0.1 mSv. Bone scans (99mTc) are about 3 mSv. DEXA scans and limb X-rays have negligible doses (<1 day background).

topics.text: Mirel's score predicts the likelihood of an impending pathologic fracture based on location (upper limb, lower limb, proximal femur), appearance (sclerotic, mixed, lytic), size (<1/3, <2/3, >2/3), and pain level (no pain, moderate pain, unable to WB). A score of 8 or more suggests an impending fracture requiring intervention.

topics.text: Plaster of Paris casts are inexpensive and mouldable but heavy and not waterproof. Both are used for fracture immobilization, with the choice depending on specific clinical needs and cost considerations.

A comprehensive hip examination involves assessing the patient standing (pelvic obliquity, scars, muscle wasting, leg length discrepancy, gait, Trendelenburg test), lying down (pelvic squareness, leg lengths, assessing correctability of deformities), palpation (greater trochanter, groin, paraspinal muscles), and assessing range of motion (flexion, abduction, adduction, internal/external rotation) using tests like the Thomas test. Examining the spine, knee, and neurovascular status is also crucial.

In a patient with an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals pelvic obliquity, compensatory scoliosis, hyper-lordosis, leg length discrepancy requiring a shoe raise, and a surgical scar. There is no active hip flexion, abduction, or rotation, and any attempted motion results in pelvic tilt. Gait is asymmetric, slow, and involves compensatory mechanisms like equinus and contralateral knee flexion. A false positive Trendelenburg test can occur due to the fixed pelvis.

Spinal examination involves inspection from the front and back to assess alignment, asymmetry, skin changes, and muscle wasting. Gait assessment is crucial, evaluating for Trendelenburg, ataxia, heel-toe walking, pigeon walking, and Romberg's sign. Palpation of spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for spasm, and assessment of joint ROM with provocative tests (Spurling's, Lhermitte's for cervical; SLR, bowstring, femoral stretch for lumbar) are essential. A thorough neurological examination assessing tone, motor power (MRC grade), myotomes, sensation, and reflexes is mandatory.
